commit_message:
Add listing tested APIs

In the Icehouse design summit QA session, we've discussed "coverage
analysis tooling" and decided to refresh and use this patch[1].
This patch is for catching called Nova APIs and creating a report on
integration tests. When start catching, every called API will be caught.
To enable this function, 'api_coverage=True' is needed in nova.conf.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/icehouse-summit-qa-coverage-tooling

blueprint: list-tested-apis
DocImpact

Change-Id: Id8ca66380f83478a335982dcf11ec9498cf223a4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/82/25882/23 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
# vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2013 NEC Corporation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json from lxml import etree import os import routes import tempfile import webob.dec from webob import exc from nova.api import openstack as base_api from nova.api.openstack import wsgi from nova.openstack.common import log as logging from nova import wsgi as base_wsgi """ To enable API Coverage, edit 'api_coverage=True' at nova.conf. """ LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class APICoverageController(wsgi.Controller): """The API-Coverage report API controller for the OpenStack API.""" # TODO(myamazaki): Controllers below have 'action' methods and # each action API is branched from the methods. # The actions are hard-coded below because they are not implemented by # thiers names nor registered to wsgi_action in Resource object but # they should be removed. action_hard_coded = { 'nova.api.openstack.compute.contrib.coverage_ext.CoverageController': [ 'start', 'stop', 'report' ], 'nova.api.openstack.compute.contrib.fixed_ips.FixedIPController': [ 'reserve', 'unreserve' ], 'nova.api.openstack.compute.contrib.aggregates.AggregateController': [ 'add_host', 'remove_host', 'set_metadata' ], } def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): self.data_path = tempfile.mkdtemp(prefix='api-coverage_') self.map = base_api.compute.APIRouter().map self._started = False self._coverage_apis = [] super(APICoverageController, self).__init__(**kwargs) def _controller(self, controller_obj): '''Retrieve controller name.''' controller = controller_obj.__str__() if controller.startswith("<bound method"): return controller.split(" ")[4][1:] elif controller.startswith("<"): return controller.split(" ")[0][1:] else: return controller def _create_api_list(self): '''Create Nova API list from mapping data of APIRouter.''' api_list = [] for route in self.map.matchlist: if route.conditions: method = route.conditions.get('method', '') else: method = [''] method = ','.join(method) routepath = route.routepath if '.:(format)' in routepath: continue action = route.defaults.get('action', None) resource = route.defaults.get('controller', None) if isinstance(resource, wsgi.Resource): controller = resource.controller wsgi_actions = resource.wsgi_actions else: continue if action == 'action': if hasattr(controller, action): # Each api action is branched in action method. controller_path = self._controller(controller) action_names = self.action_hard_coded.get(controller_path) for action_name in action_names: info = dict(method=method, path=routepath, request_action=action_name) api_list.append(info) else: # Api actions are registered in Resource object. for wsgi_action in wsgi_actions: if wsgi_action in routes.mapper.COLLECTION_ACTIONS or\ wsgi_action in routes.mapper.MEMBER_ACTIONS: continue info = dict(method=method, path=routepath, request_action=wsgi_action) api_list.append(info) else: if hasattr(controller, action) or action in wsgi_actions: info = dict(method=method, path=routepath, request_action=None) api_list.append(info) return api_list def _is_started_coverage(self): return self._started def _start_coverage(self, req): '''Create API list if it is empty.''' if self._coverage_apis == []: self._coverage_apis = self._create_api_list() for api in self._coverage_apis: api['called'] = 0 self._started = True def _stop_coverage(self, req): self._started = False def _report_coverage(self, req, body): self._stop_coverage(req) body = body['report'] if 'file' in body.keys(): path = body['file'] if path != os.path.basename(path): msg = _("Invalid path") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) path = os.path.join(self.data_path, path) else: msg = _("No path given for report file") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) called_total = 0 max_path_len = 0 for api in self._coverage_apis: if api['called'] > 0: called_total = called_total + 1 if len(api['path']) > max_path_len: max_path_len = len(api['path']) fout = open(path, "wb") try: path_format = "{0:<%s}" % max_path_len fout.write("Tested API: %d/%d
" % (called_total, len(self._coverage_apis))) fout.write("Tested No Method %s Action
" % path_format.format("Path")) for api in self._coverage_apis: index = self._coverage_apis.index(api) fout.write("%6d %03d %-6s %s %s
" % ( api['called'], self._coverage_apis.index(api), api['method'], path_format.format(api['path']), api['request_action'] if api['request_action'] else '')) finally: fout.close() return dict(path=path) def _reset_coverage(self, req): self._coverage_apis = [] def _retrieve_api(self, req): '''each called apis are checked in this method.''' result = self.map.routematch(environ=req.environ) if not result: LOG.debug(_("API NOT Found. %s %s
") % (req.method, req.path_url)) return route = result[1] method = req.method path = route.routepath action = route.defaults['action'] controller = route.defaults['controller'].controller if action != 'action': request_action = None else: try: xml_body = etree.fromstring(req.body) request_action = xml_body.tag.replace( "{%s}" % wsgi.XMLNS_V11, "") except etree.XMLSyntaxError: request_action = json.loads(req.body).keys()[0] for api in self._coverage_apis: if api['method'] == method and api['path'] == path\ and api['request_action'] == request_action: api['called'] = api['called'] + 1 LOG.debug(_("API Found: %(method)s %(path)s" " %(request_action)s
") % locals()) return LOG.debug(_("API NOT Found: %(method)s %(path)s " "%(request_action)s
") % locals()) def action(self, req, body=None): _actions = { 'start': self._start_coverage, 'report': self._report_coverage, 'reset': self._reset_coverage, } for action, data in body.iteritems(): if action == 'start' or action == 'reset': return _actions[action](req) elif action == 'report': return _actions[action](req, body) else: msg = _("API Coverage doesn't have %s action") % action raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=_("Invalid request body")) class APICoverage(base_wsgi.Middleware): """Retrieve called apis.""" name = "ApiCoverage" alias = "os-api-coverage" namespace = ("http://docs.openstack.org/compute/ext/" "apicoverage/api/v1.1") updated = "2013-03-29T00:00:00+00:00" def __init__(self, application, **kwargs): mapper = routes.Mapper() self.api_coverage_controller = APICoverageController() wsgi_resource = wsgi.Resource(self.api_coverage_controller) collection_actions = {"action": "POST"} member_actions = {} kargs = dict( controller=wsgi_resource, collection=collection_actions, member=member_actions) mapper.resource("os-api-coverage", "/{project_id}/os-api-coverage", **kargs) self._router = routes.middleware.RoutesMiddleware(self._dispatch, mapper) super(APICoverage, self).__init__(application) @webob.dec.wsgify(RequestClass=base_wsgi.Request) def __call__(self, req): if self.api_coverage_controller._is_started_coverage(): self.api_coverage_controller._retrieve_api(req) req.environ['extended.app'] = self.application return self._router @staticmethod @webob.dec.wsgify(RequestClass=base_wsgi.Request) def _dispatch(req): match = req.environ['wsgiorg.routing_args'][1] if not match: return req.environ['extended.app'] app = match['controller'] return app

commit_message:
Enforce sorting for requirements file with blankline and comments

Some requirements or test-requirements file contain comments and
blankline which is important to help users to read the file.
Change the check method to allow the file be indivded into some
blocks with blankline

Change-Id: I5466a5258f23a5ba66e85d5b34dc644aee94d840

The cinder quota test was of bad quality, and assumed that all
the functions in the class ran in linear order to work. If they
run in a different order the tenant could have additional quota

We can fix this by testing the returned quota contains the values

Change-Id: I53a154aac61368b7c20ac5703f3877fcf42f9781
"}]
commit_message:
fix cinder quota equality

The cinder quota test was of bad quality, and assumed that all
the functions in the class ran in linear order to work. If they
run in a different order the tenant could have additional quota
values beyond the strict defaults.

We can fix this by testing the returned quota contains the values
we're attempting to update.

Closes-Bug: #1291926

Change-Id: I53a154aac61368b7c20ac5703f3877fcf42f9781
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/03/81503/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add CRUD functionnal tests to assembly

This patch use the plan_uri to pass in the plan_uuid.

Change-Id: I8378a140c93fdd8e2234bfd2844eb25b24692c47
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/05/77305/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sample_data = {"name": "test_assembly", "description": "A test to create assembly", "project_id": "project_id", "user_id": "user_id"} plan_sample_data = {"name": "test_plan", "description": "A test to create plan", "project_id": "project_id", "user_id": "user_id"} def _assert_output_expected(self, body_data, data): self.assertEqual(body_data['user_id'], data['user_id']) self.assertEqual(body_data['project_id'], data['project_id']) self.assertEqual(body_data['description'], data['description']) self.assertEqual(body_data['plan_uuid'], data['plan_uuid']) self.assertEqual(body_data['name'], data['name']) self.assertIsNotNone(body_data['uuid']) def _delete_assembly(self, uuid, plan_uuid): resp, _ = self.client.delete('v1/assemblies/%s' % uuid) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 204) self._delete_plan(plan_uuid) def _delete_plan(self, plan_uuid): resp, _ = self.client.delete('v1/plans/%s' % plan_uuid) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 204) def _create_assembly(self): plan_uuid = self._create_plan() sample_data['plan_uuid'] = plan_uuid jsondata = json.dumps(sample_data) resp, body = self.client.post('v1/assemblies', jsondata) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 201) out_data = json.loads(body) uuid = out_data['uuid'] self.assertIsNotNone(uuid) return uuid, plan_uuid def _create_plan(self): jsondata = json.dumps(plan_sample_data) resp, body = self.client.post('v1/plans', jsondata) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 201) out_data = json.loads(body) uuid = out_data['uuid'] self.assertIsNotNone(uuid) return uuid def test_assemblies_create(self): plan_uuid = self._create_plan() sample_data['plan_uuid'] = plan_uuid sample_json = json.dumps(sample_data) resp, body = self.client.post('v1/assemblies', sample_json) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 201) json_data = json.loads(body) self._assert_output_expected(json_data, sample_data) self._delete_assembly(json_data['uuid'], json_data['plan_uuid']) def test_assemblies_get(self): uuid, plan_uuid = self._create_assembly() resp, body = self.client.get('v1/assemblies/%s' % uuid) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 200) json_data = json.loads(body) self._assert_output_expected(json_data, sample_data) self._delete_assembly(uuid, plan_uuid) def test_assemblies_put(self): uuid, plan_uuid = self._create_assembly() updated_data = {"name": "test_assembly updated", "description": "A test to create assembly updated", "plan_uuid": plan_uuid, "project_id": "project_id updated", "user_id": "user_id updated"} updated_json = json.dumps(updated_data) resp, body = self.client.put('v1/assemblies/%s' % uuid, updated_json) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 200) json_data = json.loads(body) self._assert_output_expected(json_data, updated_data) self._delete_assembly(uuid, plan_uuid) def test_assemblies_delete(self): uuid, plan_uuid = self._create_assembly() resp, body = self.client.delete('v1/assemblies/%s' % uuid) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 204) self.assertEqual(body, '') self._delete_plan(plan_uuid)

subject: Change report_interval from 4 to 30, agent_down_time from 9 to 75
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-16 11:05:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d6c361d7a90c085f270b880f47851072f5b1271c', 'message': "Change report_interval from 4 to 28, agent_down_time from 9 to 60

report_interval is how often an agent sends out a heartbeat to the
service. The Neutron service responds to these 'report_state' RPC
messages by updating the agent's heartbeat DB record.
The last heartbeat is then compared to the configured
agent_down_time to determine if the agent is up or down.
The agent's status is used when scheduling networks on DHCP
and L3 agents.

In the spirit of sane defaults suited for production, these values
should be bumped to reduce the load on the Neutron service
dramatically, freeing up CPU time to perform intensive operations.

Closes-Bug: #1293083
Change-Id: I77bcf8f66f74ba55513c989caead1f96c92b9832

commit_message:
Change report_interval from 4 to 30, agent_down_time from 9 to 75

report_interval is how often an agent sends out a heartbeat to the
service. The Neutron service responds to these 'report_state' RPC
messages by updating the agent's heartbeat DB record.
The last heartbeat is then compared to the configured
agent_down_time to determine if the agent is up or down.
The agent's status is used when scheduling networks on DHCP
and L3 agents.

In the spirit of sane defaults suited for production, these values
should be bumped to reduce the load on the Neutron service
dramatically, freeing up CPU time to perform intensive operations.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1293083
Change-Id: I77bcf8f66f74ba55513c989caead1f96c92b9832
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/29/80829/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # agent_down_time = 60# report_interval = 28

commit_message:
Update sqlalchemy migrate scripts for postgres

pgsql <= 8.3 was lax about char->other casting but this was tightened
up in 8.4+. We must now specify the USING clause for such a cast to
succeed. The SQL queries generated by sqlalchemy for pgsql don't
support this, so an override is needed to support pgsql for the trove
migrate scripts.

Closes-bug: 1293465
Change-Id: I217fc861036911e61bafe706e338bb3b8f49e708
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/73/81073/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # pgsql <= 8.3 was lax about char->other casting but this was tightened up # in 8.4+. We now have to specify the USING clause for the cast to succeed. # NB: The generated sqlalchemy query doesn't support this, so this override # is needed. if migrate_engine.name == 'postgresql': migrate_engine.execute('ALTER TABLE instances ALTER COLUMN flavor_id ' 'TYPE INTEGER USING flavor_id::integer') else: instances = Table('instances', meta, autoload=True) #modify column instances.c.flavor_id.alter(type=Integer()) # int->char casts in pgsql still work fine without any USING clause, # so downgrade is not affected.

commit_message:
Adapting to use the python-saharaclient library

Changes to use python-saharaclient library which come as part
of the savanna to sahara renaming project.
*  This requires python-saharaclient to be released as
   requirements.txt now depends on it.

Partial-Implements:  blueprint savanna-renaming-dashboard

Change-Id: I0da5efb3f8398c3108ec51be5858951396cddca5

commit_message:
Host and service api no longer work with cells

The host and service api no longer work with
cells because in cells a host and service ID
is <cell routing path>@<ID>. While the real
id of host and service in DB must be int,
remove the operation of changing id to string.

Change-Id: I580695c3e546cd7cfc7c6dbada37fcf94759a18b
Closes-bug: #1251043

commit_message:
VMware: bug fix for host operations when using VMwareVCDriver

Currently the driver does not have a mapping between a Nova 'host'
and a VMware 'cluster'. A host operation would update the state of
one of the hosts in one of the configured clusters.

The solution is for the driver to raise a NotImplemented exception.

Change-Id: Idd78020374a6fe2d34bf8d860c30e2ed8c719903
Closes-bug: #1274129

commit_message:
Cells: Send instance object for instance_delete_everywhere

The delete method in the compute api expects an instance object to be
passed in. So the instance object needs to not be to_primitived in the
instance_delete_everywhere rpc method.

Change-Id: I620ec57bc28ba11335758455c7cac0bfa63f5b37
Closes-bug: #1293750

commit_message:
libvirt: handle NoneType vcpu info in get_vcpu_used

The old libvirt(e.g. 0.9.x) return None rather than -1
while get the vcpu info of a domain failed, and python-libvirt
does not raise a libvirtError exception in this situation,
this may be a libvirt bug, but we should make nova be compatible
with it.

Closes-bug: #1294509
Change-Id: Iad18d002c8e1640af049b3312783440e02a7f552

subject: Stop removing ip allocations on port delete
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-18 07:52:29.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py', 'neutron/db/l3_db.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2648aa3561d23e1215e0cc6f446253e5df56c8f6', 'message': 'Stop removing ip allocations on port delete

The _delete_port() method was manually removing related
IPAllocation instances despite the existence of a perfectly
good cascade deletion relationship in the model.  This patch
puts an end to that nonsense and the potential for deadlock that
it represented.

Closes-bug: #1288379
Related-Bug: #1283522

Change-Id: Ib31550fa9000fc75768a327cb6cc1c419e06568f
'}]
commit_message:
Stop removing ip allocations on port delete

The _delete_port() method was manually removing related
IPAllocation instances despite the existence of a perfectly
good cascade deletion relationship in the model.  This patch
puts an end to that nonsense and the potential for deadlock that
it represented.

Closes-bug: #1288379
Related-Bug: #1283522

Change-Id: Ib31550fa9000fc75768a327cb6cc1c419e06568f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/96/81196/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add redhat-common element

Add an element intended for use in both Fedora and RHEL.  This
allows them to share install steps that are common to both.

Change-Id: Ie4e820a7b777b8701514351b1f802cfe57c3812e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/66/74866/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -e if [ -d /etc/first-boot.d ]; then rc_local=/etc/rc.d/rc.local FILE_EXISTED= if [ -f $rc_local ] then FILE_EXISTED=1 mv $rc_local $rc_local.REAL fi dd of=$rc_local <<EOF #!/bin/bash set -e set -o xtrace dib-first-boot EOF if [ $FILE_EXISTED ] then echo "mv $rc_local.REAL $rc_local" >> $rc_local else echo "rm \$0" >> $rc_local fi echo "exit 0" >> $rc_local chmod 755 $rc_local # Enable the service systemctl enable rc-local.service fi

commit_message:
Fix Grizzly to Havana migration of quota_usages table

Migration script 216 clears quota_usages table when the user_id is null
then attempts to repopulate it with data from other tables. Migration
203 adds the user_id column to quota_usages and sets them to null
initially so migration 216 will wipe the entire quota_usages table.
There's a bug in the migration since it queries the quota_usages table
for the possible resources after this table is empty.

Closes-Bug:1245746

Change-Id: I7c7948c2b4a70bc42c4a5580737dec3e8863f0d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/81669/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: resource_tuples = select(columns=[quota_usages.c.resource], distinct=True).execute().fetchall() resources = [resource[0] for resource in resource_tuples]
deleted_lines: resource_tuples = select(columns=[quota_usages.c.resource], distinct=True).execute().fetchall() resources = [resource[0] for resource in resource_tuples]

subject: Fix re-schedule causing attached volume conflicts
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-07-21 15:27:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/60227df21bdbef853f32146b8db65c0ae65fc672', 'message': 'Add protection in createVM

Due to re-scheduler mechanism, create VM from attached-volume will not only cause the volume-state overwritten on Cinder side, but also confuse the attached-relation on Nova side.

Need to raise exception directly when the situation above occured.

Change-Id: Ib45c11604e167f3ee3d14874fe297beeb5a2c8ec
Fixes: bug/1195947
author: wingwj

Due to re-scheduler mechanism, when a user tries to create (in error) an instance using a volume which is already in use by another instance, the error is correctly detected, but the recovery code will incorrectly affect the original instance.

Need to raise exception directly when the situation above occured.

commit_message:
Fix re-schedule causing attached volume conflicts

Due to re-scheduler mechanism, when a user
tries to create (in error) an instance using a volume
which is already in use by another instance,
the error is correctly detected, but the recovery code
will incorrectly affect the original instance.

Need to raise exception directly when the situation above occured.

P.S. Updated on Mar 19th:

Due to the Iefab71047996b7cc08107794d5bc628c11680a70
doesn't catch up with the Icehouse.

So we need to use the Havana patch
I6b68965ac65cdb0e1da3b44e83428f056b1693aa
to fix this issue instead.

Change-Id: Ib45c11604e167f3ee3d14874fe297beeb5a2c8ec
Closes-Bug: #1195947

commit_message:
Adds tempest tests to cover update_item functionality

Adds negative tests on update item from nonexistent and
creating table.
Adds negative tests on update item with wrong expected
parameter.
Adds negative tests on update item with invalid and empty
key.

Partially implements: bp increase-tempest-test-coverage
Change-Id: I9d793f0a6f27ca6cad8568ee07f96926748b4074

commit_message:
VMware: iscsi target discovery fails while attaching volumes

VMware Drivers are unable to discover iscsi targets because
the api calls fail to specify the iscsi server location
(referred in the code as target portal) to retrieve targets.
This is critical for the attach_volume feature to work with
iscsi supported cinder drivers.

Closes-Bug: #1235112

Change-Id: I60c06ae651bb2eb6d466a5ca61a09f289c21d1a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/92/49692/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def create_host_storage_system(): host_storage_system = HostStorageSystem() _create_object("HostStorageSystem", host_storage_system) def _add_iscsi_send_tgt(self, method, *args, **kwargs): """Adds a iscsi send target to the hba.""" send_targets = kwargs.get('targets') host_storage_sys = _get_objects('HostStorageSystem').objects[0] iscsi_hba_array = host_storage_sys.get('storageDeviceInfo' '.hostBusAdapter') iscsi_hba = iscsi_hba_array.HostHostBusAdapter[0] if hasattr(iscsi_hba, 'configuredSendTarget'): iscsi_hba.configuredSendTarget.extend(send_targets) else: iscsi_hba.configuredSendTarget = send_targets elif attr_name == "AddInternetScsiSendTargets": return lambda *args, **kwargs: self._add_iscsi_send_tgt(attr_name, *args, **kwargs) elif attr_name == "RescanHba": return lambda *args, **kwargs: self._just_return_task(attr_name)

commit_message:
API layer documentation

* Discuss the WSGI layer of Neutron
* Describe the startup code that creates the WSGI application
* Briefly discuss the URL routing and resource creation

Change-Id: Id82a2a5679d7e29c0a19d1a20942a9249946b011
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/75/79675/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This section will cover the internals of Neutron's HTTP API, and the classes in Neutron that can be used to create Extensions to the Neutron API. Python web applications interface with webservers through the Python Web Server Gateway Interface (WSGI) - defined in `PEP 333: <http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0333/>`_ Startup ------- Neutron's WSGI server is started from the `server module <http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron/tree/neutron/server/__init__.py>`_ and the entry point `serve_wsgi` is called to build an instance of the `NeutronApiService`_, which is then returned to the server module, which spawns a `Eventlet`_ `GreenPool`_ that will run the WSGI application and respond to requests from clients. .. _NeutronApiService: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron/tree/neutron/service.py .. _Eventlet: http://eventlet.net/ .. _GreenPool: http://eventlet.net/doc/modules/greenpool.html WSGI Application ---------------- During the building of the NeutronApiService, the `_run_wsgi` function creates a WSGI application using the `load_paste_app` function inside `config.py`_ - which parses `api-paste.ini`_ - in order to create a WSGI app using `Paste's`_ `delpoy`_. The api-paste.ini file defines the WSGI applications and routes - using the `Paste INI file format <http://pythonpaste.org/deploy/#applications>`_. The INI file directs paste to instantiate the `APIRouter`_ class of Neutron, which contains several methods that map Neutron resources (such as Ports, Networks, Subnets) to URLs, and the controller for each resource. .. _Paste: http://pythonpaste.org/ .. _Delpoy: http://pythonpaste.org/deploy/ .. _api-paste.ini: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron/tree/etc/api-paste.ini .. _APIRouter: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron/tree/neutron/api/v2/router.py Further reading ---------------

Renaming files with savanna words in its names

* Removed etc/savanna directory:

  and updated setup.cfg according that

Co-Authored-By: Trevor McKay <tmckay@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use strict assertion in Cinder quota update

Cinder automatically creates an unlimited default quota for volume types
once the first volume is created. If volume creation tests are done
before this default quota update test, it would fail due to not knowing
about volume type quotas that were created earlier. This assertion
change just checks specifically the quotas that were updated.

Closes-Bug: #1291162
Change-Id: Iec66b89d1d7f3c9442a2e32fc931efa9a6a163d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/26/81426/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix invalid vim call in vim_util.get_dynamic_properties()

Code was calling
vim.CancelRetrievePropertiesEx(token=obj_content.token)

This will be translated into a call to
vim_request_handler(managed_object, **kwargs) by Vim.__getattr__(),
which requires a managed_object argument.

This change also adds a test for vim_util.get_dynamic_properties which
exercises both property retrieval, and the cancellation of an
unfinished RetrieveResult.

Change-Id: Ie0d98cbded4dee680593d2a950510de25ee5fab7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/52/69652/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: vim.CancelRetrievePropertiesEx( vim.get_service_content().propertyCollector, token=obj_content.token)

commit_message:
VMware: Add a test helper to mock the suds client

Change-Id: I326abd0ee5a4b1512c34a63de5fea6a7ba1b6f77
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/70707/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import contextlib import mock def fake_suds_context(calls={}): '''Generate a suds client which automatically mocks all SOAP method calls. Calls are stored in <calls>, indexed by the name of the call. If you need to mock the behaviour of specific API calls you can pre-populate <calls> with appropriate Mock objects.''' class fake_factory: def create(self, name): return mock.NonCallableMagicMock(name=name) class fake_service: def __getattr__(self, attr_name): if attr_name in calls: return calls[attr_name] mock_call = mock.MagicMock(name=attr_name) calls[attr_name] = mock_call return mock_call class fake_client: def __init__(self, wdsl_url, **kwargs): self.service = fake_service() self.factory = fake_factory() return contextlib.nested( mock.patch('suds.client.Client', fake_client), # As we're not connecting to a real host there's no need to wait # between retries mock.patch.object(driver, 'TIME_BETWEEN_API_CALL_RETRIES', 0) )

commit_message:
Ignore .coverage* files

When a coverage command aborts, some temporary files related to the
coverage remain like this:
    .coverage.localhost.24409.990268
    .coverage.localhost.24415.503858
    .coverage.localhost.24417.953422
    .coverage.localhost.24419.169526
    .coverage.localhost.24421.143443
    .coverage.localhost.24423.259249
    .coverage.localhost.24425.429360
    .coverage.localhost.24427.025521
    .coverage.localhost.24432.204681
    .coverage.localhost.24479.725555
We should not manage these files in the git repository.

Partially implements bp unit-tests

Change-Id: Ifa5aaa526b27473c5e5220a5be4a910603676e60
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/78/80878/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Stop test server leaking even if an error happens

Some api/compute test creates multiple test-servers in setUpClass(). But
if an error happens, some servers are not deleted because
tearDownClass() is not called.
This commit fixes it.

Partially Implements: blueprint stop-leaking

Change-Id: I448bf844a19cd88da0dd3a6da162711307e34b30

commit_message:
Add saharaclient to global requirements

The python-saharaclient 0.6.0 release is a fully renamed version of ex.
savanna client with backward compat for both python bindings and cli,
so, we're planning to switch external projects requirements to the
saharaclient package imports and sahara cli command usage and then remove
python-savannaclient from the global requirements.

Change-Id: I97ea6560580931452c8739e4f6961412c873dac1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/83/81083/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python-saharaclient>=0.6.0

commit_message:
Git url validation

* Reads validation rules from Oslo Config 'validate' group
* Checks url max length and regex for security
* Adds a new InvalidInput exception for these kinds of checks

Partially implements: blueprint solum-input-validation
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/solum/+spec/solum-input-validation

Change-Id: Ie48ae35b59aee32534cece082e43abdf7cd96c9d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/42/79042/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [validation] # # Options defined in solum.common.validate # # The longest git url acceptable (integer value) #git_url_max_len=255 # The git url validation regex (string value) #git_url_regex=a^

commit_message:
WIP: Check that scripts are set -e

WIP reason: Before I go through and fix up all of the set calls
in the elements, I want a consensus on what we should be
enforcing here.  I think -e definitely makes sense, probably -u,
and possibly -x.  -e for the reasons below, -u for similar reasons,
and -x is helpful for debugging, but it does tend to clutter up the
logs somewhat so I don't know that we want to enforce it.

When element scripts are not set -e, it's possible for failures to
be ignored and then bite us later when deploying the image.  It's
better to catch those errors when they happen.

Change-Id: I3ba94d1f399df0c5bd67ba93ac7fa030a271aaa0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/52/79352/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Check that all scripts are set -e # NOTE(bnemec): This doesn't verify that the set call occurs high # enough in the file to be useful, but hopefully nobody will be # sticking set calls at the end of their file to trick us. And if # they are, that's easy enough to catch in reviews. if [ -n "$(echo $firstline | grep '#!/bin/[b]*[a]*sh')" ]; then sete=$(grep "set -[^ ]*e" $i) if [ -z "$sete" ]; then echo "ERROR: $i is not set -e" rc=1 fi fi

commit_message:
Enforce alphabetical ordering in element-deps

We're doing this manually in reviews anyway now, so we might as
well let Jenkins handle it for us.

Change-Id: Ibba4136f7da1c01fbe49b70f242c99238ddd1382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/51/79351/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TMPDIR=$(mktemp -d) trap "rm -rf $TMPDIR" EXIT # Check alphabetical ordering of element-deps if [ $(basename $i) = "element-deps" ]; then UNSORTED=${TMPDIR}/element-deps.unsorted SORTED=${TMPDIR}/element-deps.sorted grep -v '^#' $i > ${UNSORTED} sort ${UNSORTED} > ${SORTED} diff -c ${UNSORTED} ${SORTED} if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then echo "ERROR: $i is not sorted alphabetically" rc=1 fi fi

commit_message:
Relax regex when keystone refuses connections

Seems newer python-keystoneclient have a different excpetion message,
specifically they dropped the HTTP prefix.  Now we allow both messages to be
trapped.

Add some additional cases that are common regex now covers
 (HTTP 400)
 [Errno 111] Connection refused
 503 Service Unavailable
 Max retries exceeded
 HTTP Unable to establish connection
 Unable to establish connection to http://...

Change-Id: I71fada12b3dbb681288c7ef2891603f970910736
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <paul.belanger@polybeacon.com>
Signed-off-by: Andrew Woodward <awoodward@mirantis.com>

Ensure json file is initialised

commit_message:
New SSL extension

Note: This change is a continuation of a previous change
that was abandoned due to rebase issues (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/63510)

Adding new ssl extension for ssl-termination support
in neutron.
Extension is not served by lbaas plugin
but is extending lbaas vip with ssl entities associations

Creating new abstract driver for ssl api
Adding new absract driver as a base to radware driver

Adding ssl dbmixin for ssl policies and certificates
management.
If service provider (driver) is not inheriting from new
abstract ssl driver - new "ExtensionNotSupportedByProvider"
exception is raised.

Since association of ssl certificates and vip requires
sending a list on certificates, list support was needed
in neutron resource attributes parsing mechanism.
I added the lists support and extended unit tests to test it.

Added unit tests for extension and db mixin

Alembic migration was added for the change

Radware driver and its unit tests are WIP, do not review.

Change-Id: Ie6468f0488ea2515ed8ccbe1a8c9c55b9ab4a3de
Implements: blueprint lbaas-ssl-termination
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/12/81612/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ExtensionNotSupportedByProvider(NeutronException): message = _("Extension %(extension_name)s is not supported by " " %(provider_name)s provider")

commit_message:
Change remaining 'savanna' references in sahara/tests

These changes remove the remaining 'savanna' references under the
'tests' dir to 'sahara' and modify necessary files outside of
'tests' to make unit and integration tests pass.

* Change member savanna_config to sahara_config for alembic
* Change description strings in sahara/resources
* Change exception strings in plugin validation
* Change tests/README
* Change param names, defaults, and help in integration tests config.py
* Change alembic migration test lock prefix
* Change SAVANNA_MYSQL_PRESENT and SAVANNA_TEST_POSTGRESQL_PRESENT in
  alembic tests
* Change 'Generated by' message in crypto.py

Partial-Implements: blueprint savanna-renaming-service
Change-Id: I11e1bab1fce76a411a8659b947e7bae90ea521a9

commit_message:
Add get_item API v1 method

Implements blueprint: os-restful-api-get-item
Change-Id: If6beba2ea53bac36c61ef1ecf50295e2ec957a2e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnetodb refs/changes/95/81595/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Mirantis Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import httplib import json import mock import unittest from magnetodb.tests.fake import magnetodb_api_fake class GetItemTestCase(unittest.TestCase): """The test for get_item method of openstack v1 ReST API.""" @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): magnetodb_api_fake.run_fake_magnetodb_api() @classmethod def tearDownClass(cls): magnetodb_api_fake.stop_fake_magnetodb_api() @mock.patch('magnetodb.storage.select_item') def test_create_table(self, mock_select_item): headers = {'Content-Type': 'application/json', 'Accept': 'application/json'} conn = httplib.HTTPConnection('localhost:8080') url = '/v1/fake_project_id/data/tables/the_table/get_item' body = """ { "key": { "ForumName": { "S": "Amazon DynamoDB" }, "Subject": { "S": "How do I update multiple items?" } }, "attributes_to_get": ["LastPostDateTime","Message","Tags"], "consistent_read": true } """ conn.request("POST", url, headers=headers, body=body) response = conn.getresponse() self.assertTrue(mock_select_item.called) json_response = response.read() response_payload = json.loads(json_response) self.assertEqual({'item': {}}, response_payload)

commit_message:
Update docstring for baremetal opportunistic tests

The db.test_migrations can test the migrations for Nova and nova
bare-metal. This patch updates the docstring on how to run those
tests opportunistically.

Change-Id: I327d688ec9af7dc0e8e0e58804bac8a3091cb727
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/73453/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: For the opportunistic testing you need to set up db's named 'openstack_citest' and 'openstack_baremetal_citest' with user 'openstack_citest' and password 'openstack_citest' on localhost. The test will then use that db and u/p combo to run the tests.
deleted_lines: For the opportunistic testing you need to set up a db named 'openstack_citest' with user 'openstack_citest' and password 'openstack_citest' on localhost. The test will then use that db and u/p combo to run the tests.

commit_message:
Implement environment selector logic, make draft design for it.

Implemented logic includes:
* setting default environment on App Catalog page
* setting default environment upon pressing Add Application button at
  Environments->Services with immediate redirect to App Catalog page
* storing default environment in request.session

Implements: blueprint current-environment-selector

Change-Id: I1d98103efd645c6f1a3183679dee37c7d712486f

commit_message:
Fix incorrect info in volume client docstring

The v2 xml and json volume client have incorrect documentation for
the "display_name" parameter used for the create_volume operation.
This commit fixes this and updates a helper method in the v2 base
volume test to use the fixed parameter.

Change-Id: I4480b76b99e73317af830a9610b762843e44c60d
Closes-bug: #1294270

commit_message:
Add swift discoverable_api support to verify_tempest_config

This commit adds support to the verify_tempest_config.py script
for detecting which swift apis are enabled.

Partially implements bp config-verification

Change-Id: I7f4a1fdc41246b3584aa5d3faca5920ca5c2f6e5

subject: Prevent attach volume race when compute is down
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-18 13:12:42.000000000', 'files': ['nova/exception.py', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/extended_volumes.py', 'nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/test_extended_volumes.py', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/volumes.py', 'nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/contrib/test_volumes.py', 'nova/tests/compute/test_compute.py', 'nova/compute/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/27787c98feacb2de61c7cf24a3db0dfec8118314', 'message': 'Prevent attach volume race when compute is down

As described in the linked bug, if the compute service is down, and
there is a volume attach request, there is a window where
reserve_block_device rpc message may stay on the message bus, which can
cause inconsistent behaviour.

This patch introduces 2 changes that will mitigate this. The first one
is that we will check if the compute service where the instance is
running is up, and if not we will fail the request. This is a
reasonable thing to do since we cannot possibly complete the attach
request at such time and it is better to let the user know that
what he is expecting to happen cannot happen at this time. Since some
attach requests can now return a 503 HTTP status this commit will have

DocImpact

In addition, the EC2 API will now respond with an InternalError.

The second change is that we move the volume reservation before the
reserve_block_device call. This will result in volume being kept in
"attaching" state until the request completes, thus making the window
where volume can be mistaken for available while we are waiting for a
delayed RPC call much smaller.

Closes-bug: #1180040
Change-Id: I73c3ec051add59fce4053a64f42e24e74b8de71f
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent attach volume race when compute is down

As described in the linked bug, if the compute service is down, and
there is a volume attach request, there is a window where
reserve_block_device rpc message may stay on the message bus, which can
cause inconsistent behaviour.

This patch introduces 2 changes that will mitigate this. The first one
is that we will check if the compute service where the instance is
running is up, and if not we will fail the request. This is a
reasonable thing to do since we cannot possibly complete the attach
request at such time and it is better to let the user know that
what he is expecting to happen cannot happen at this time. Since some
attach requests can now return a 503 HTTP status this commit will have

DocImpact

In addition, the EC2 API will now respond with an InternalError.

The second change is that we move the volume reservation before the
reserve_block_device call. This will result in volume being kept in
"attaching" state until the request completes, thus making the window
where volume can be mistaken for available while we are waiting for a
delayed RPC call much smaller.

Closes-bug: #1180040
Change-Id: I73c3ec051add59fce4053a64f42e24e74b8de71f

commit_message:
Ensure to count firewalls in target tenant

Previously admin tenant cannot create a firewall if other tenant
already created a firewall. We need to count firewalls only in
a target tenant.

Change-Id: I3e6d151d00d4a487bdd858e94929fab8960511a2
Closes-Bug: #1258438

commit_message:
Mock agent RPC for FWaaS tests to delete DB objs

This changes the firewall service unit tests to
mock the RPC calls from the firewall service to
the agent. This allows the tests to fake the
agent response RPC that removes the firewall
from the DB so the all of the other objects that
the firewall depends on can be deleted.

Closes-Bug: #1288441
Change-Id: I32462ab5557b9c52328bf6a23a12efc2d799644c

commit_message:
Remove IDENTIFIED BY clause for MySQL REVOKE

IDENTIFIED BY is not documented for REVOKE in MySQL 5.5 and 5.6 and
furthermore produces a syntax error on MySQL 5.6.

Change-Id: Ib7bf1ba0ce049c1ed8a90292064a1e05724170e0
Closes-Bug: #1292690

commit_message:
Make tools/integration.sh take a branch

Instead of always using master branch support the option to use stable
branches. Read the branch via the $OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH environmental
variable that devstack-gate sets

Change-Id: Iab4ae1efddc4dca38dcd3779dae1a79ddc2b0852

This patch does a lot of trivial changes. But all changes belong to two
things.

The first thing is to make clear that when we could put traceback in rally

----------------------------------------
|  err type    |  [0]  |  [1]  |  [2]  |
| normal mode  |   N   |   N   |   N   |
| verbose mode |   N   |   N*  |   Y   |
|  debug mode  |   N   |   Y   |   Y   |
----------------------------------------

Why need the [1] between [0] and [2]? The reason is that OpenStack APIs
always return something hard to explain[3]. In another word, we need some
*hacking* for it in rally codes. At least we have to parse it in a way
different with [0] and [2].

The second thing is improving error message so that we could understand
output better. An easy example is that when updating resource status,
the old output always said "resource is in ERROR status". Who is it?
What's the reason for it? This is what this patch is trying to tell you.

Firstly some exception message is improved:

GetResourceFailture: telling users *which resource* failed and *why*
GetResourceNotFound: telling users *which resource* is not found
GetResourceErrorStatus: telling users *which resource* is in a *error
                        status* and *why* (if possible)

And print fault message of nova servers.

[0] Server side fault
[1] Client side fault caused by server side
[2] Client side fault
[3] bug #1280453

Change-Id: I3082a72b6547493ed19def83847fe8f6e9ff0e2f

commit_message:
improve rally output (exception part)

This patch does a lot of trivial changes. But all changes belong to two
things.

The first thing is to make clear that when we could put traceback in rally
output. There is a strategy:

----------------------------------------
|  err type    |  [0]  |  [1]  |  [2]  |
| normal mode  |   N   |   N   |   N   |
| verbose mode |   N   |   N*  |   Y   |
|  debug mode  |   N   |   Y   |   Y   |
----------------------------------------

Why need the [1] between [0] and [2]? The reason is that OpenStack APIs
always return something hard to explain[3]. In another word, we need some
*hacking* for it in rally codes. At least we have to parse it in a way
different with [0] and [2].

The second thing is improving error message so that we could understand
output better. An easy example is that when updating resource status,
the old output always said "resource is in ERROR status". Who is it?
What's the reason for it? This is what this patch is trying to tell you.

Firstly some exception message is improved:

GetResourceFailture: telling users *which resource* failed and *why*
GetResourceNotFound: telling users *which resource* is not found
GetResourceErrorStatus: telling users *which resource* is in a *error
                        status* and *why* (if possible)

And print fault message of nova servers.

[0] Server side fault
[1] Client side fault caused by server side
[2] Client side fault
[3] bug #1280453

Change-Id: I3082a72b6547493ed19def83847fe8f6e9ff0e2f

commit_message:
Volume boot test uses new block device syntax

This patch adds a new test that tests the volume boot with the new block
device mapping syntax that was added to Nova in Havana.

For more details on the v2 block device mapping syntax see the following
Wiki page: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/BlockDeviceConfig

Change-Id: Ie15d62fded79dd19e896f6317123597f70ed3f6e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/26/79626/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _boot_instance_from_volume_v1(self, vol_id, keypair): def _boot_instance_from_volume_v2(self, vol_id, keypair): bdms = [{'uuid': vol_id, 'source_type': 'volume', 'destination_type': 'volume', 'boot_index': 0, 'delete_on_termination': False}] create_kwargs = { 'block_device_mapping_v2': bdms, 'key_name': keypair.name } return self.create_server(image='', create_kwargs=create_kwargs) def _test_volume_boot_pattern(self, boot_method): instance_1st = getattr(self, boot_method)(volume_origin.id, keypair) instance_2nd = getattr(self, boot_method)(volume_origin.id, keypair) instance_from_snapshot = getattr(self, boot_method)(volume.id, keypair) @test.services('compute', 'volume', 'image') def test_volume_boot_pattern_old_format(self): self._test_volume_boot_pattern('_boot_instance_from_volume_v1') @test.services('compute', 'volume', 'image') def test_volume_boot_pattern_new_format(self): self._test_volume_boot_pattern('_boot_instance_from_volume_v2')
deleted_lines: def _boot_instance_from_volume(self, vol_id, keypair): def test_volume_boot_pattern(self): instance_1st = self._boot_instance_from_volume(volume_origin.id, keypair) instance_2nd = self._boot_instance_from_volume(volume_origin.id, keypair) instance_from_snapshot = self._boot_instance_from_volume(volume.id, keypair)

commit_message:
Ensure insecure config option propagated by alarm evaluator

Fixes bug 1292130

Ensure insecure (i.e. non-cert-verifying) access over SSL to
keystone works from the alarm threshold evaluator for
statistics queries and alarm state transitions.

Change-Id: Idb94fa96a6a8b32bd071af1f73fd3172ae6948ad

commit_message:
Catch InstanceNotFound exceptions for V2 API virtual interfaces

Use the common.get_instance method to get the instance object
in the V2 API virtual interfaces extension rather than call
the compute api directly. The utility function
handes InstanceNotFound exceptions and tranlsates them to HTTPNotFound
rather than letting them propagate up causing a traceback.

Co-Authored-By: Michael Still <mikal@stillhq.com>

Change-Id: I8abee22c53195926e3d2af1da9b14cd9d3608e63
Closes-Bug: 1270804

commit_message:
Chef-client fail on dnsmasq package download.

Because github have to mutch http redirect chef-client failed with a error on dnsmasq pkg download
To fix this error we should use a more direct url to download the dnsmasq pkg.

Change-Id: I18e9900b7140606b5ae0bf318ce8f04f7a62d544
Closes-Bug: #1294656

commit_message:
Avoid error when creating private flavor

Avoid trying to add the current project to the flavor
access list since it is added by novamanage when the
flavor is crated

Change-Id: I4ff466a9614062938d25d2bd1750b6ad60b82227
Closes-Bug: #1286297

subject: Simplify test force delete snapshot unit test
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-17 05:37:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/fad43109cc7014249f44543b53e426c9fcb7648b', 'message': "Keep local path the same in test force snap delete

Everytime self.driver.local_path() was called in this test, it would
create another temporary file to stub the local path of the snapshot.
This would sometimes result in a test failure because
cinder.volume.drivers.lvm.LVMVolumeDriver._clear_volume() would check if
local_path() existed, in which sometimes the file wasn't created in time
of the check.

Closes-Bug: #1291108
Change-Id: If10b1057cf170e77527a0933a1ddf1a6a59baa1d
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-03-18 03:04:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/7bff5c2ac4764ab78197a43f50f2b5b20e4faf4e', 'message': "Create tmp file early in test force snap delete

This test stubs local_path() to create a tmp file to represent
a snapshot. This file however would be created close to the time it was
being checked if it still existed, resulting in sometimes the file not
being created in time of the check. Instead, create the file ahead of
time in the test to ensure it's created before the check if it exists
happens.

Closes-Bug: #1291108
Change-Id: If10b1057cf170e77527a0933a1ddf1a6a59baa1d
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-03-18 22:03:28.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/api/contrib/test_admin_actions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/71853a32111ec9a36f8a2082b41b52519b66be85', 'message': "Simplify test force delete snapshot unit test

Make this test simple in just verifying if we have a snapshot and we do
a force delete that we get back an ok response from the controller.
Removing out RPC call and verifying snapshot was deleted since that's
out of the scope here.

Closes-Bug: #1291108
Change-Id: If10b1057cf170e77527a0933a1ddf1a6a59baa1d
"}]
commit_message:
Simplify test force delete snapshot unit test

Make this test simple in just verifying if we have a snapshot and we do
a force delete that we get back an ok response from the controller.
Removing out RPC call and verifying snapshot was deleted since that's
out of the scope here.

Closes-Bug: #1291108
Change-Id: If10b1057cf170e77527a0933a1ddf1a6a59baa1d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/95/80895/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(flaper87): Instead of patch `os.path.exists` create a fake path # for the snapshot that should be deleted and let the check pass. Strip # `-cow` since it'll be added later in the happy path. tfile = tempfile.mkstemp(suffix='-cow', dir=self.tempdir) tfile_path = tfile[1].strip('-cow') def local_path(volume, vg=None): return tfile_path
deleted_lines: # NOTE(flaper87): Instead fo patch `os.path.exists` # create a fake path for the snapshot that should # be deleted and let the check pass def local_path(volume, vg=None): tfile = tempfile.mkstemp(suffix='-cow', dir=self.tempdir) # NOTE(flaper87): Strip `-cow` since it'll be added # later in the happy path. return tfile[1].strip('-cow')

subject: Make LIVE Tests configurable with ENV
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-13 22:04:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/e226993783e377c7c897bc59623f383451d893f0', 'message': 'Make LIVE Tests configuable with ENV

To enable ldap live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_LDAP_LIVE_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

To enable tls ldap live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_TLS_LDAP_LIVE_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

To enable mysql sql live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_LIVE_MYSQL_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

To enable postgres sql live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_LIVE_POSTGRES_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

To enable db2 sql live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_LIVE_DB2_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

This allows for running all tests in a standard run by simply setting
the appropriate environmental variables.

This moves the live tests to be skips if the specific live-test
environmental variables are not set.

``ENABLE_LIVE_DB2_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

This allows for running all tests in a standard run by simply setting
the appropriate environmental variables.

This moves the live tests to be skips if the specific live-test
environmental variables are not set.

commit_message:
Make LIVE Tests configurable with ENV

To enable ldap live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_LDAP_LIVE_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

To enable tls ldap live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_TLS_LDAP_LIVE_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

To enable mysql sql live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_LIVE_MYSQL_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

To enable postgres sql live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_LIVE_POSTGRES_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

To enable db2 sql live test, set the environmental variable
``ENABLE_LIVE_DB2_TESTS`` to a non-false value.

This allows for running all tests in a standard run by simply setting
the appropriate environmental variables.

This moves the live tests to be skips if the specific live-test
environmental variables are not set.

Change-Id: I8c09a8dcfca3f9691306c5f416f688205171bda3
Closes-Bug: 1243392
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/09/80409/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.tests import test_ldap_livetestclass LiveTLSLDAPIdentity(test_ldap_livetest.LiveLDAPIdentity): def _ldap_skip_live(self): self.skip_if_env_not_set('ENABLE_TLS_LDAP_LIVE_TEST')

but that test case should be scenario anyway.

commit_message:
Enable run_ssh and add floatingip + keypair auth

Make the instance validation tests neutron and gate friendly.

The instance validation code part got several additional option, in
order to be able to use the old method when it is needed.

The old method expected the fixed/private ip externally reachable and
the shadow file on the instance is changeable by n-cpu.

The cirros image has limited data command so the uptime check is changed.
Cirros does not sets the hostname according to the metadata
so the hostname verification is skipped.
The volume+reboot test still requires the 'adminpass' auth method,
but that test case should be scenario anyway.

The ssh connection after rebooting has an issue so the
test_reboot_server_hard is skipped.

Implements: blueprint ssh-auth-strategy

Change-Id: If8e1e2cb5fc078f8c0c6308f1baf98558dbb5814
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/37/50337/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.StrOpt('ssh_auth_method', default='keypair', help="Auth method used for authenticate to the instance." "Valid chooses are: keypair, configured, adminpass." "keypair: start the servers with an ssh keypair." "configured: use the configured user and passord." "Adminpass: use the injected adminPass."), cfg.StrOpt('ssh_connect_method', default='floating', help="How to connect to the instance ?" "fixed: using the first ip belongs the fixed network" "floating: creating and using a floating ip"),

commit_message:
change dirty logs to work off a whitelist

instead of marking the logs that we think should be clean, mark
the ones we think should be dirty. This means no new services can
come in with unclean logs.

remove the whitelist data, as that's currently obsolete, we'll
remove the code for it later.

commit_message:
Remove individual cfg.CONF.resets from tests

oslo.config.CONF.reset is added to cleanup in BaseTestCase, so it does
not need to be done by individual test cases.

Change-Id: I5fced5c2d480e78e5bb7cc150f0b653313884456
Closes-Bug: #1291144

commit_message:
Simplify graph analyzer interface

All you need to get next nodes to schedule is call get_next_nodes()
method -- it will work correctly for tasks in any state with any
intention. This makes graph action code much simpler.

Change-Id: Idc89e98c928b3a7d8d29a4e007658e88c4326228

commit_message:
Add user-supplied arguments in log_handler

When using PublishErrorsHandler, it will missing user-supplied
arguments. For example, do LOG.info("blabla %s", "foo"),
the payload only contains "blabla %s", but we expect it like
"blabla foo". this bug has been fixed in oslo, just syncs it to
ceilometer.
Sync from Oslo, change-id: I91289cc4a60f5dab89bca852e6f52b4b83831e47

Change-Id: Ic2773035f6899e1ba7ec2813f79bd271dfa36b97

subject: Add container forwarding support to updater daemon
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-14 10:15:47.000000000', 'files': ['swift/container/updater.py', 'swift/container/sync.py', 'test/unit/common/middleware/test_keystoneauth.py', 'test/unit/container/test_sync.py', 'swift/account/server.py', 'swift/common/middleware/keystoneauth.py', 'test/unit/container/test_fwd_updater.py', 'swift/proxy/controllers/account.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/6ec0e9d285d3b557f605bbdb021754bea995b6c1', 'message': "Add container forwarding support to updater daemon

This is one of a set of patches implementing a container-forwarding feature.
(see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/cluster-federation)

Normally the updater daemon digs info out of a container DB and
PUTs it to all the account servers for the container's account.

In the case of a forwarded container the home container simply
contains a reference to a target container on another cluster
and so has 0 objects and 0 bytes itself. Updating the account
servers with 0,0 is not very useful...

So the updater daemons that runs on the home cluster and the target
cluster need to be changed to either, in the case of a home cluster,
fetch the container info from the target cluster and update the
account servers with that, or in the case of a target cluster, get
info out of the container DB and report it back to the home cluster.

The updater daemon figures out whether it's dealing with a forwarded
container by looking for 'x-container-attr-fwd-*' metadata in the
container DB. If the daemon finds a 'x-container-attr-fwd-dest' key
it's found the home part of a forwarded container and uses the value
of the 'x-container-attr-fwd-dest' key as a URL from which to fetch
info using HEAD. If the daemon finds a 'x-container-attr-fwd-src' key
it's found the target part of a forwarded container and uses the value
of the 'x-container-attr-fwd-src' key as a URL to which it reports
info using POST. [It currently does not use PUT as PUTs are only
enabled if Swift is configured to allow account management]

The reason the updater code has been modified to do both fetch and
report is two-fold:
1. Report is more efficient as reports are only sent if data has
changed.
2. Fetch could be a 'belt-and-braces' tactic to handle the cases
where report is not working. Also fetch is the only way that a missing
target container can be detected and fixed.
Note on any given cluster updater daemons can fetch OR report - they
can not do both.

By default the updater daemon acts as it always has and completely
ignores forwarded containers. To configure it to take account of
forwarded containers it needs to be configured with cf_mode 'report',
'fetch' or 'fetchfix' - the latter is an augmented fetch that cleans
up when a missing target container is detected.
The updater daemon can be configured with separate intervals for
reporting, fetching and fixing (cf_report_interval, cf_fetch_interval
and cf_fetch_fix_missing_interval). Timestamps are written into the
container DB to allow these intervals to be honoured and preserved
across multiple passes of the daemon.

To allow these modifications to work a number of other changes had to
be made:
1. swift/account/server.py translates a POST into a PUT
2. swift/proxy/controllers/account.py makes account POST a
delay_denial OP and calls swift.authorize
3. swift/common/middleware/keystoneauth.py allows the daemon
(via a secret key) to do both HEADs and POSTs
4. swift/container/sync.py is modified to prevent home containers
being sync'd elsewhere - they're empty so it's pointless
5. numerous tests

Change-Id: I95f0d0b90184f4472f70dcead75f1a8c5b789546
Implements: blueprint cluster-federation
"}]
commit_message:
Add container forwarding support to updater daemon

This is one of a set of patches implementing a container-forwarding feature.
(see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/cluster-federation)

Normally the updater daemon digs info out of a container DB and
PUTs it to all the account servers for the container's account.

In the case of a forwarded container the home container simply
contains a reference to a target container on another cluster
and so has 0 objects and 0 bytes itself. Updating the account
servers with 0,0 is not very useful...

So the updater daemons that runs on the home cluster and the target
cluster need to be changed to either, in the case of a home cluster,
fetch the container info from the target cluster and update the
account servers with that, or in the case of a target cluster, get
info out of the container DB and report it back to the home cluster.

The updater daemon figures out whether it's dealing with a forwarded
container by looking for 'x-container-attr-fwd-*' metadata in the
container DB. If the daemon finds a 'x-container-attr-fwd-dest' key
it's found the home part of a forwarded container and uses the value
of the 'x-container-attr-fwd-dest' key as a URL from which to fetch
info using HEAD. If the daemon finds a 'x-container-attr-fwd-src' key
it's found the target part of a forwarded container and uses the value
of the 'x-container-attr-fwd-src' key as a URL to which it reports
info using POST. [It currently does not use PUT as PUTs are only
enabled if Swift is configured to allow account management]

The reason the updater code has been modified to do both fetch and
report is two-fold:
1. Report is more efficient as reports are only sent if data has
changed.
2. Fetch could be a 'belt-and-braces' tactic to handle the cases
where report is not working. Also fetch is the only way that a missing
target container can be detected and fixed.
Note on any given cluster updater daemons can fetch OR report - they
can not do both.

By default the updater daemon acts as it always has and completely
ignores forwarded containers. To configure it to take account of
forwarded containers it needs to be configured with cf_mode 'report',
'fetch' or 'fetchfix' - the latter is an augmented fetch that cleans
up when a missing target container is detected.
The updater daemon can be configured with separate intervals for
reporting, fetching and fixing (cf_report_interval, cf_fetch_interval
and cf_fetch_fix_missing_interval). Timestamps are written into the
container DB to allow these intervals to be honoured and preserved
across multiple passes of the daemon.

To allow these modifications to work a number of other changes had to
be made:
1. swift/account/server.py translates a POST into a PUT
2. swift/proxy/controllers/account.py makes account POST a
delay_denial OP and calls swift.authorize
3. swift/common/middleware/keystoneauth.py allows the daemon
(via a secret key) to do both HEADs and POSTs
4. swift/container/sync.py is modified to prevent home containers
being sync'd elsewhere - they're empty so it's pointless
5. numerous tests

Change-Id: I95f0d0b90184f4472f70dcead75f1a8c5b789546
Implements: blueprint cluster-federation

commit_message:
use DIB_REPOLOCATION_ if set in pull-tools script

 pull-tools contains a static list of urls for the tripleo tool repos.
 This change allows DIB_REPOLOCATION_<tool> envars, if set, to override
 defaults, otherwise the default urls are used, as per before.

commit_message:
WIP - Implement Fixed IP PTR Record API

This change adds support for fixed IPs to the API.  This work extends
the work done for handling floating IPs.

blueprint fixed-ip-ptrs

Change-Id: Ia13aea659d53f61f06985a27dd14ccf5422a023e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/09/80309/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def list_ports(self, context, region=None): """ Get ports based on the current context from Neutron """ endpoints = self._endpoints( service_catalog=context.service_catalog, service_type='network', endpoint_type=CONF['network_api:neutron'].endpoint_type, config_section='network_api:neutron', region=region) tg = threadgroup.ThreadGroup() failed = [] data = [] def _call(endpoint, region, *args, **kw): client = get_client(context, endpoint=endpoint) LOG.debug("Attempting to fetch Ports from %s @ %s", endpoint, region) try: ports = client.list_ports(*args, **kw) except neutron_exceptions.Unauthorized as e: # NOTE: 401 might be that the user doesn't have neutron # activated in a particular region, we'll just log the failure # and go on with our lives. msg = "Calling Neutron resulted in a 401, please investigate." LOG.warning(msg) LOG.exception(e) return except Exception as e: LOG.error('Failed calling Neutron %s - %s', region, endpoint) LOG.exception(e) failed.append((e, endpoint, region)) return LOG.debug(ports) for port in ports['ports']: for fixed_ip in port['fixed_ips']: data.append({ 'device_id': port['device_id'], 'address': fixed_ip['ip_address'], 'region': region }) LOG.debug("Added %i Ports from %s @ %s", len(data), endpoint, region) for endpoint, region in endpoints: tg.add_thread(_call, endpoint, region, tenant_id=context.tenant_id) tg.wait() # NOTE: Sadly tg code doesn't give us a good way to handle failures. if failed: msg = 'Failed retrieving Ports from Neutron in %s' % \ ", ".join(['%s - %s' % (i[1], i[2]) for i in failed]) raise exceptions.NeutronCommunicationFailure(msg) return data

commit_message:
test for adding crazy branches

as found by dansmith's clever hack, if devstack lands a crazy
branch name in stackrc, we'd break the devstack gate. While it's
doubtful anyone would do this, add a basic sanity check.

Change-Id: Ib3b1881ed4fd520a1828ed073a7c8353e6f0a839
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/06/78706/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Test that no one is trying to land crazy refs as branches echo "Ensuring we don't have crazy refs" REFS=`grep BRANCH stackrc | grep -v -- '-master'` rc=$? if [[ $rc -eq 0 ]]; then echo "Branch defaults must be master. Found:" echo $REFS exit 1 fi

subject: Improve Neutron subnets management
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-10 21:44:08.000000000', 'files': ['spec/unit/provider/neutron_subnet/neutron_spec.rb', 'lib/puppet/type/neutron_subnet.rb', 'lib/puppet/provider/neutron_subnet/neutron.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron/commit/e0f7c0efed9fa9a39c0e6eb55bd16c48a6a4e5aa', 'message': 'Improve Neutron subnets management

Previously, subnet had some parameters as read-only which blocks some
features, like specifing dns servers, allocation pools and also specific
host routes.
This patch aims to add support for these options as well for creation
and also for update (for some of them where API allows it).

Change-Id: Ibf71fa8577ca8799cdd5767726e9c0ea4a23a5fc
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Improve Neutron subnets management

Previously, subnet had some parameters as read-only which blocks some
features, like specifing dns servers, allocation pools and also specific
host routes.
This patch aims to add support for these options as well for creation
and also for update (for some of them where API allows it).

Change-Id: Ibf71fa8577ca8799cdd5767726e9c0ea4a23a5fc
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/62/79462/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if @resource[:allocation_pools] opts << "--allocation-pool #{@resource[:allocation_pools]}" end if @resource[:dns_nameservers] opts << "--dns-nameservers #{@resource[:dns_nameservers]}" end if @resource[:host_routes] opts << "--host-routes #{@resource[:host_routes]}" end opts << "--tenant-id=#{@resource[:tenant_id]}" def dns_nameservers=(value) auth_neutron('subnet-update', "--dns-nameservers #{value}", name) end def host_routes=(value) auth_neutron('subnet-update', "--host-routes #{value}", name) end :allocation_pools,

commit_message:
Take a vm out of SNAPSHOTTING after Glance error

If a snapshot is attempted to be taken when Glance can't find the
underlying image (usually because it's been deleted), then ImageNotFound
is raised to nova.compute.manager.ComputeManager._snapshot_instance. The
error path for this leaves the instance in a snapshotting state; after
which "operator intervention" is required.

This simply reverts the instance state under that specific circumstance.

DocImpact: previously a snapshot that failed for this reason would leave
the instance in a spurious snapshotting task state indefinitely. Now,
the task state is reverted. At the moment that revert is 'silent'
(although the failure to snapshot will be evident to the user).

Fixes-bug: #1267097
(cherry picked from commit 96dba50737819c24b4ddd9cb1078da305638abc9)

Conflicts:

	nova/compute/manager.py

Change-Id: I9623cfaed31e8337ab65bc1eab85ad3b51b1a5ca

commit_message:
Add utility method in service handler

This new method will only create a service when the given type
does not already exist.

Change-Id: I7d53f412218d5126837f97eeb30dbc5cd977dac9

added_lines: from sqlalchemy.orm import exc from solum.common import exceptionfrom solum.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy import session as db_session @classmethod def get_by_type(cls, context, service_type): try: session = db_session.get_session(mysql_traditional_mode=True) return session.query(cls).filter_by( service_type=service_type).one() except exc.NoResultFound: raise exception.NotFound(id=type, name='service type')

commit_message:
Add a template for design specs.

Add a template for specs.  This covers the general formatting we
expect, as well as the level of detail we are looking for.

Change-Id: I03fcb6ad178bb0099612b0e19b3f4c1a209a94bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/41/81441/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Delete this paragraph when you write your blueprint. However, here are some simple instructions. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . * ============================= The title of your blueprint ============================= Put the URL of your blueprint on launchpad here, as well as any other related blueprints. Introduction paragraph -- why are we doing anything? A single paragraph of prose that operators can understand. This blueprint is Copyright (C) Danny Nerdflubble Industries 2014. Detailed problem description ============================ A detailed description of the problem. For a new feature this might be use cases, for a major reworking of something existing it would describe the problems in that feature that are being addressed. Proposed change =============== Here is where you cover the change you propose to make. Some things to consider: - How will the feature be used? You could call this the user interface. It might take various forms: - For an API extension, API samples are required, *NOT* simply nova command line examples. - Does this change have an impact on python-novaclient? What does the user interface there look like? - If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? - Consistency of the user experience is also important. Some concrete examples: - What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? - If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other hypervisors would implement the feature is required. - If this is one part of a larger effort make it clear where this piece ends. In other words, what's the scope of this effort? Dependancies ============ - Include specific references to specs in other projects that this one either depends on or is related to. - If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Nova (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. - Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Implementation ============== Who is writing the code? Is anyone signed up to do the work? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Cover upgrade impact -- how will deploying this change affect existing users? For example, if we change the directory name that instances are stored in, how do we handle instance directries created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the instances in their cloud? Alternative implementations =========================== What other ways could we do this thing? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed implementation is the appropriate one. Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated.

commit_message:
Workaround failing pypy gate job

Until a proper fix is found, pin the version of setuptools to one
that doesn't cause this issue.

Change-Id: I4f5f2b6449a90df06b366f9eb3f2c16bb37cc758
Related-Bug: #1290562
