./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_resources.xml:90(emphasis) msgid "Systems administration"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_resources.xml:92(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_resources.xml:97(emphasis)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_resources.xml:99(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_resources.xml:103(emphasis) msgid "Configuration management" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_resources.xml:105(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_resources.xml:108(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:13(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:91(title)msgid "Each OpenStack cloud is different and as a result, even with what may seem a near-identical architecture to this guide, you must still test upgrades between versions in your environment. For this, you will need an approximate clone of your environment."msgid "However, that is not to say that it needs to be the same size, or using identical hardware as the production environment few of us have that luxury. It is important to consider the hardware, and scale of the cloud you are upgrading, but here are some tips to avoid that incredible cost:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:40(para) msgid "Use your own cloud. The simplest place to start testing the next version of OpenStack is by setting up a new environment inside your own cloud. This may seem odd - especially the double virtualisation used in running compute nodes - but it's a sure way to very quickly test your configuration."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:45(para) msgid "Use a public cloud. Especially as your own cloud is unlikely to have sufficient space to scale test to the level of the entire cloud, consider using a public cloud to test the scalability limits of your cloud controller configuration. Most public clouds bill by the hour, which means it can be inexpensive to perform even a test with many nodes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:51(para) msgid "Make another storage endpoint on the same system. If you use an external storage plugin or shared filesystem with your cloud, in many cases it's possible to test that it works by creating a second share or endpoint. This will enable you to test the system before entrusting the new version onto your storage."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:56(para) msgid "Watch the network. Even at smaller scale testing, it should be possible to determine if something is going horribly wrong in inter-component communication if you look at the network packets and see too many."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:61(para) msgid "To actually set up the test environment, there are several methods. Some prefer to do a full manual install using the OpenStack Installation Guides, and then see what the final configuration files look like, and which packages were installed. Others prefer to create a clone of their Automated Configuration infrastructure with changed package repository URLs and then alter the configuration until it starts working. Either approach is valid, and depends on experience."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:70(para) msgid "An upgrade pre-testing system is excellent for getting the configuration to work, however it is important to note that the historical use of the system and differences in user interaction can affect the successfulness of upgrades, too. We've seen experiences where database migrations encountered a bug (later fixed!) due to slight table differences between fresh Grizzly installs and those which migrated from Folsom to Grizzly."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:77(para) msgid "As artificial scale testing can only go so far, once upgraded, you'll also need to pay careful attention to the performance aspects of your cloud."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:82(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:83(para) msgid "Like all major system upgrades, your upgrade could fail for one or more difficult-to-determine reasons. You should prepare for this situation by leaving the ability to roll back your environment to the previous release including databases, configuration files, and packages. We provide an example process for rolling back your environment in ."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:92(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:95(para) msgid "Perform some 'cleaning' of the environment prior to starting the upgrade process to ensure a consistent state. For example, instances not fully purged from the system after deletion may cause indeterminate behavior."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:102(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:106(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:109(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:114(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:118(para) msgid "You can perform an upgrade with operational instances, but this strategy can be dangerous. You might consider using live migration to temporarily relocate instances to other compute nodes while performing upgrades. However, you must ensure database consistency throughout the process otherwise your environment may become unstable. Also, don't forget to provide sufficient notice to your users including giving them plenty of time to perform their own backups."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:126(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:130(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:134(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:137(para) msgid "Upgrade OpenStack Compute (nova) including networking components."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:141(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:144(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:147(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:151(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:155(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:159(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:163(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:167(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:172(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:174(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Havana. All nodes should run Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services such as the Identity Service (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova) including networking, Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:184(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:435(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:185(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:436(para) msgid "The upgrade process will interrupt management of your environment including the dashboard. If you properly prepare for this upgrade, tenant instances will continue to operate normally."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:191(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:442(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:192(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:443(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:199(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:449(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:200(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:450(para) msgid "Save the configuration files on all nodes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:208(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:458(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:211(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:461(para) msgid "Back up all databases on the controller."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:215(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:465(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:216(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:466(para) msgid "On all nodes, remove the repository for Grizzly packages and add the repository for Havana packages."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:221(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:471(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:225(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:479(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:226(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:480(para) msgid "Update the Glance configuration on the controller node for compatibility with Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:228(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:482(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:241(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:248(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:517(para) msgid "Update the Nova configuration on all nodes for compatibility with Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:250(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:519(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:254(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:258(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:526(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:269(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:539(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:274(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:544(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:281(para) msgid "You must restart Dnsmasq and the networking component of Compute to enable the new DHCP lease time."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:285(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:554(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:287(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:556(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:291(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:295(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:563(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:300(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:568(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:302(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:570(para) msgid "The dashboard installation procedure and configuration file changed substantially between Grizzly and Havana. Particularly, if you are running Django 1.5 or later, you must ensure that /etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings contains a correctly configured ALLOWED_HOSTS key which contains a list of hostnames recognized by the dashboard."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:309(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:577(para) msgid "If users will access your dashboard using \"http://dashboard.example.com\", you would set:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:312(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:580(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:315(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:583(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:320(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:588(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:321(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:589(para) msgid "Upgrade packages on the controller node to Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:323(para) msgid "Depending on your specific configuration, performing a dist-upgrade may restart services supplemental to your OpenStack environment. For example, if you use Open-iSCSI for Block Storage volumes and the upgrade includes a new open-scsi package, the package manager will restart Open-iSCSI services which may cause disconnection of volumes for your users."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:333(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:342(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:610(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:343(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:611(para) msgid "Stop each service, run the database synchronization command if necessary to update the associated database schema, and restart each service to apply the new configuration. Some services require additional commands."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:368(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:371(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:642(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:375(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:646(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:376(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:647(para) msgid "Upgrade packages on the compute nodes to Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:378(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:407(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:649(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:665(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:383(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:389(para) msgid "You can fix this issue using the following command."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:393(para) msgid "The packaging system will ask about updating the /etc/nova/api-paste.ini file. Like the controller upgrade, we recommend denying these changes and reviewing the .dpkg-dist file after completing the upgrade process."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:398(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:656(para) msgid "Restart Compute services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:404(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:662(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:405(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:663(para) msgid "Upgrade packages on the storage nodes to Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:412(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:417(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:672(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:422(title) msgid "How to Perform an Upgrade from Grizzly to Havana - Red Hat Enterprise Linux and Derivatives"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:424(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Havana. All nodes should run Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.4 or compatible derivatives. Newer minor releases should also work. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services such as the Identity Service (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova) including networking, Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:474(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:510(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:523(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:550(para) msgid "You must restart Dnsmasq and the Nova networking service to enable the new DHCP lease time."msgid "Remove defunct database configuration from /etc/cinder/cinder.conf."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:591(para) msgid "Some services may terminate with an error during the package upgrade process. If this may cause a problem with your environment, consider stopping all services before upgrading them to Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:605(para) msgid "Install the OpenStack SELinux package on the controller node."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:653(para) msgid "Install the OpenStack SELinux package on the compute nodes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:669(para) msgid "Install the OpenStack SELinux package on the storage nodes." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:677(title) msgid "Cleaning Up and Final Configuration File Updates"msgid "On all distributions, you will need to perform some final tasks to complete the upgrade process."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:680(para) msgid "Decrease DHCP timeouts by modifying /etc/nova/nova.conf on the compute nodes back to the original value for your environment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:683(para) msgid "Update all of the .ini files to match passwords and pipelines as required for Havana in your environment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:694(para) msgid "Thoroughly test the environment and then let your users know that their cloud is running normally again."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:698(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:699(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:704(para) msgid "In this section, we only consider the most immediate case: You have taken down production management services in preparation for an upgrade, completed part of the upgrade process, discovered one or more problems not encountered during testing, and need to roll back your environment to the original \"known good\" state. We specifically assume that you did not make any state changes after attempting the upgrade process: No new instances, networks, storage volumes, etc."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:712(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:715(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:716(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:717(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:719(para) msgid "The upgrade instructions provided in earlier sections ensure that you have proper backups of your databases and configuration files. You should read through this section carefully and verify that you have the requisite backups to restore. Rolling back upgrades is a tricky process as distributions tend to put much more effort into testing upgrades than downgrades. Broken downgrades often take significantly more effort to troubleshoot and hopefully resolve than broken upgrades. Only you can weigh the risks of trying to push a failed upgrade forward versus rolling it back. Generally, we consider rolling back the very last option." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:729(para) msgid "The steps described below for Ubuntu have worked on at least one production environment, but may not work for all environments." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:733(title) msgid "Perform the Roll Back from Havana to Grizzly"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:738(para) msgid "Copy contents of configuration backup directories /etc/<service>.grizzly that you created during the upgrade process back to /etc/<service>."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:744(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:749(para) msgid "If you created this backup using the flag as instructed, you can proceed to the next step. If you omitted this flag, MySQL will revert all of the tables that existed in Grizzly, but not drop any tables created during the database migration for Havana. In this case, you will need to manually determine which tables should not exist and drop them to prevent issues with your next upgrade attempt."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:760(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:761(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:768(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:815(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:821(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:843(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:858(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:865(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:872(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_log_monitor.xml:80(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:2171(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_log_monitor.xml:95(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:2725(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_log_monitor.xml:400(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4287(glossterm)msgid "These volumes are persistent: they can be detached from one instance and re-attached to another, and the data remains intact. Block storage is implemented in OpenStack by the OpenStack Block Storage (cinder) project, which supports multiple backends in the form of drivers. Your choice of a storage backend must be supported by a Block Storage driver."msgid "Choosing Storage Backends"msgid "Users will indicate different needs for their cloud use cases. Some may need fast access to many objects that do not change often, or they want to set a Time To Live (TTL) value on a file. Others may access only storage that is mounted with the file system itself, but want it to be replicated instantly when starting a new instance. For other systems, ephemeral storagestorage that is released when a VM attached to it is shut down is the preferred way. When you select storage back-ends, ask the following questions on behalf of your users:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_storage.xml:339(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:834(glossterm)msgid "Ceph was designed to expose different types of storage interfaces to the end-user: it supports object storage, block storage, and file-system interfaces, although the file-system interface is not yet considered production-ready. Ceph supports the same API as swift for object storage and can be used as a backend for cinder block storage as well as backend storage for glance images. Ceph supports \"thin provisioning,\" implemented using copy-on-write."msgid "Gluster. A distributed, shared file system. As of Gluster version 3.3, you can use Gluster to consolidate your object storage and file storage into one unified file and object storage solution, which is called Gluster For OpenStack (GFO). GFO uses a customized version of swift that enables Gluster to be used as the backend storage."msgid "LVM. The Logical Volume Manager, a Linux-based system that provides an abstraction layer on top of physical disks to expose logical volumes to the operating system. The LVM backend implements block storage as LVM logical partitions."msgid "The ZFS back-end for OpenStack Block Storage supports only Solaris-based systems such as Illumos. While there is a Linux port of ZFS, it is not included in any of the standard Linux distributions, and it has not been tested with OpenStack Block Storage. As with LVM, ZFS does not provide replication across hosts on its own; you need to add a replication solution on top of ZFS if your cloud needs to be able to handle storage-node failures."msgid "We don't recommend ZFS unless you have previous experience with deploying it, since the ZFS back-end for Block Storage requires a Solaris-based operating system, and we assume that your experience is primarily with Linux-based systems."msgid "This section contains a small selection of use cases from the community with more technical detail than usual. Further examples can be found on the OpenStack Website (https://www.openstack.org/user-stories/)"msgid "Who uses it: Researchers from the Australian publicly funded research sector. Use is across a wide variety of disciplines, with the purpose of instances being from running simple web servers to using hundreds of cores for high throughput computing."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:30(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:84(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:170(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:213(title)msgid "Using OpenStack Compute Cells, the NeCTAR Cloud spans eight sites with approximately 4,000 cores per site."msgid "Each site runs a different configuration, as resource cells in an OpenStack Compute cells setup. Some sites span multiple data centers, some use off compute node storage with a shared file system and some use on compute node storage with a non-shared file system. Each site deploys the Image Service with an Object Storage back-end. A central Identity Service, Dashboard and Compute API Service is used. Login to the Dashboard triggers a SAML login with Shibboleth, that creates an account in the Identity Service with an SQL back-end."msgid "All sites are based on Ubuntu 12.04 with KVM as the hypervisor. The OpenStack version in use is typically the current stable version, with 5 to 10% back ported code from trunk and modifications."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:58(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:65(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:71(para) msgid "NeCTAR Website (https://www.nectar.org.au/)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:80(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:81(para) msgid "Who uses it: Researchers from the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:85(para) msgid "The CSAIL cloud is currently 64 physical nodes with a total of 768 physical cores and 3,456 GB of RAM. Persistent data storage is largely outside of the cloud on NFS with cloud resources focused on compute resources. There are more than 130 users in more than 40 projects with typically running 2,000 - 2,500 vCPUs in 300 to 400 instances."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:92(para) msgid "We initially deployed on Ubuntu 12.04 with the Essex release of OpenStack using FlatDHCP multi host networking."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:95(para) msgid "The software stack is still Ubuntu 12.04 LTS but now with OpenStack Havana from the Ubuntu Cloud Archive. KVM is the hypervisor, deployed using FAI (http://fai-project.org/) and Puppet for configuration management. The FAI and Puppet combination is used lab wide, not only for OpenStack. There is a single cloud controller node, which also acts as network controller, the remainder of the server hardware dedicated to compute nodes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:105(para) msgid "Host aggregates and instance type extra specs are used to provide two different resource allocation ratios. The default resource allocation ratios we use are 4:1 CPU and 1.5:1 RAM. Compute intensive workload use instance types that require non-oversubscribed hosts where cpu_ratio and ram_ration are both set to 1.0. Since we have HyperThreading enabled on our compute nodes this provides one vCPU per CPU thread, or two vCPU per physical core."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:114(para) msgid "With our upgrade to Grizzly in August 2013 we moved to OpenStack Networking Service, Neutron (Quantum at the time). Compute nodes have two gigabit network interfaces and a separate management card for IPMI management. One network interface is used for node to node communications. The other is used as a trunk port for OpenStack managed VLANs. The controller node uses two bonded 10g network interfaces for it's public IP communications. Big pipes are used here because images are served over this port and it is also used to connect to iSCSI storage back-ending the image storage and database. The controller node also has a gigabit interface that is used in trunk mode for OpenStack managed VLAN traffic, this port handles traffic to the dhcp-agent and metadata-proxy."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:129(para) msgid "We approximate the older nova-networking multi-host HA setup by using 'provider vlan networks' that connect instances directly to existing publicly addressable networks and use existing physical routers as their default gateway. This means that if our network controller goes down running instances will still have their network available and no single Linux host becomes a traffic bottleneck. We are able to do this because we have a sufficient supply of IPv4 addresses to cover all of our instances and thus don't need NAT and don't use floating IP addresses. We provide a single generic public network to all projects and additional existing VLANs on a project by project basis as needed. Individual projects are also allowed to create their own private GRE based networks."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:149(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:159(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:160(para) msgid "Who uses it: DAIR is an integrated virtual environment that leverages the CANARIE network to develop and test new information communication technology (ICT) and other digital technologies. It combines such digital infrastructure as advanced networking, and cloud computing and storage to create an environment for develop and test of innovative ICT applications, protocols and services, perform at-scale experimentation for deployment, and facilitate a faster time to market."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:171(para) msgid "DAIR is hosted at two different data centers across Canada: one in Alberta and the other in Quebec. It consists of a cloud controller at each location, however, one is designated as the \"master\" controller that is in charge of central authentication and quotas. This is done through custom scripts and light modifications to OpenStack. DAIR is currently running Grizzly."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:179(para) msgid "For Object Storage, each region has a Swift environment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:181(para) msgid "A NetApp appliance is used in each region for both block storage and instance storage. There are future plans to move the instances off of the NetApp appliance and onto a distributed file system such as Ceph or GlusterFS."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:186(para) msgid "VlanManager is used extensively for network management. All servers have two bonded 10gb NICs that are connected to two redundant switches. DAIR is set up to use single-node networking where the cloud controller is the gateway for all instances on all compute nodes. Internal OpenStack traffic (for example, storage traffic) does not go through the cloud controller."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:199(para) msgid "DAIR Homepage (http://www.canarie.ca/en/dair-program/about)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:208(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:209(para) msgid "Who uses it: Researchers at CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research) conducting high-energy physics research."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:214(para) msgid "The environment is largely based on Scientific Linux 6, which is Red Hat compatible. We use KVM as our primary hypervisor although tests are ongoing with Hyper-V on Windows Server 2008."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:218(para) msgid "We use the Puppet Labs OpenStack modules to configure Compute, Image Service, Identity Service and Dashboard. Puppet is used widely for instance configuration and Foreman as a GUI for reporting and instance provisioning."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:223(para) msgid "Users and Groups are managed through Active Directory and imported into the Identity Service using LDAP. CLIs are available for Nova and Euca2ools to do this."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:227(para) msgid "There are 3 clouds currently running at CERN, totaling around 3400 Nova Compute nodes, with approximately 60,000 cores. The CERN IT cloud aims to expand to 300,000 cores by 2015."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:237(para) msgid "OpenStack in Production: A tale of 3 OpenStack Clouds (openstack-in-production.blogspot.com/2013/09/a-tale-of-3-openstack-clouds-50000.html)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:245(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/app_usecases.xml:252(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_network_design.xml:370(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:1509(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/section_arch_example-nova.xml:74(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:10(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:11(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:13(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:20(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:22(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:24(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:30(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:32(para) msgid "A list of permissions attached to an object. An ACL specifies which users or system processes have access to objects. It also defines which operations can be performed on specified objects. Each entry in a typical ACL specifies a subject and an operation. For instance, ACL entry, (Alice, delete), for a file gives Alice permission to delete the file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:38(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:40(para) msgid "Alternative term for an Amazon EC2 access key. See EC2 Access key."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:45(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:47(para) msgid "The swift context of an account. Do not confuse with a user account from an authentication service such as Active Directory, /etc/passwd, OpenLDAP, OpenStack Identity Service, and so on."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:54(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:56(para) msgid "Checks for missing replicas, incorrect, and corrupted objects in a specified swift account by running queries against the back-end SQLite database."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:63(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:65(para) msgid "A SQLite database that contains swift accounts and related metadata and is accessed by the accounts server."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:71(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:73(para) msgid "A swift worker that scans for and deletes account databases that are marked for deletion on an account server."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:79(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:81(para) msgid "Lists containers in swift and stores container information in the account database."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:86(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:88(para) msgid "A swift component that provides account services such as list, create, modify, and audit. Do not confuse with OpenStack Identity Service, OpenLDAP, or similar user account services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:95(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:97(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:103(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:105(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:109(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:111(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:119(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:121(para) msgid "Authentication and Identity Service by Microsoft, based on LDAP. Supported in OpenStack."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:127(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:129(para) msgid "In a high availability setup with an active/passive configuration, systems are set up to bring additional resources online to replace those that have failed."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:137(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:139(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:146(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:148(para) msgid "A subset of API calls that are accessible to authorized administrators and are generally not accessible to end users or the public internet, can exist as a separate service (keystone) or can be a subset of another API (nova)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:156(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:158(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:163(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:166(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:173(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:175(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:181(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:183(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:190(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:192(para) msgid "The process of taking floating IP address from the address pool so it can be associated with a fixed IP on a guest VM instance."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:198(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:200(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:207(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:214(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:205(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:212(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:219(glossterm) msgid "AMQP" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:221(para) msgid "Advanced Message Queue Protocol. An open Internet protocol for reliably sending and receiving messages. Devices are weighted by size."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4938(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4940(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4945(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4947(para) msgid "A daemon that listens to a queue and carries out tasks in response to messages. For example, the cinder-volume worker attaches storage to instances."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4961(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4963(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4965(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4970(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4976(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4978(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4984(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:4998(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:5008(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:5010(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:5012(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:5018(glossterm)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/glossary-terms.xml:5020(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:69(None)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:690(None)msgid "To create a project through the OpenStack Dashboard:"msgid "Select the Admin tab in the left hand navigation bar."msgid "You are prompted for a project name and an optional, but recommended, description. Select the check box at the bottom of the form to enable this project. By default, it is enabled."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:73(para) msgid "It is also possible to add project members and adjust the project quotas. We'll discuss those later, but in practice it can be quite convenient to deal with all these operations at one time."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:76(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:79(para) msgid "This command creates a project named \"demo\". Optionally, you can add a description string by appending --description tenant-description which can be very useful. You can also create a group in a disabled state by appending --enabled false to the command. By default, projects are created in an enabled state."msgid "Typically, default values are changed because a tenant requires more than the OpenStack default of 10 volumes per tenant, or more than the OpenStack default of 1TB of disk space on a Compute node."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:120(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:121(para) msgid "OpenStack Havana introduced a basic quota feature for the Image service so you can now restrict a project's image storage by total number of bytes. Currently, this quota is applied cloud-wide, so if you were to set an Image quota limit of 5 GB, then all projects in your cloud will only be able to store 5 GB of images and snapshots."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:126(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:130(para) msgid "For example, to restrict a project's image storage to 5 GB:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:133(para) msgid "In the Icehouse release, there is a configuration option in glance-api.conf that limits the number of members allowed per image, called image_member_quota, set to 128 by default. That setting is a different quota than the storage quota."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:152(td)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:154(td) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:497(td)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:175(para) msgid "Floating Ips" msgstr "" msgid "Ram"msgid "Megabytes of instance ram allowed per tenant."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:292(para) msgid "Security Groups" msgstr "" msgid "View and update Compute quotas for a tenant (project)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:327(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:541(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:358(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:578(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:359(replaceable) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:389(replaceable) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:563(replaceable) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:579(replaceable)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:392(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:582(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:393(replaceable) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:583(replaceable)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:393(replaceable) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:583(replaceable)msgid "Container Quotas: Limits the total size (in bytes) or number of objects that can be stored in a single container."msgid "Account Quotas: Limits the total size (in bytes) that a user has available in the Object Storage service."msgid "In order to take advantage of either container quotas or account quotas, your Object Storage proxy server must have container_quotas or account_quotas (or both) added to the [pipeline:main] pipeline. Each quota type also requires its own section in the proxy-server.conf file:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:451(para) msgid "To view and update Object Storage quotas, use the swift command provided by the python-swiftclient package. Any user included in the project can view the quotas placed on their project. In order to update Object Storage quotas on a project, you must have the role of ResellerAdmin in the project that the quota is being applied to."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:457(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:467(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:470(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:473(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:486(title) msgid "Set Block Storage quotas"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:487(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:492(caption)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:504(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:507(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:512(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:515(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:521(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:524(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:532(title) msgid "View and update Block Storage quotas for a tenant (project)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:534(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:539(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:554(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:560(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:562(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:576(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:583(replaceable)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:600(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:601(para) msgid "The command line tools for managing users are inconvenient to use directly. They require issuing multiple commands to complete a single task, and they use UUIDs rather than symbolic names for many items. In practice, humans typically do not use these tools directly. Fortunately, the OpenStack Dashboard provides a reasonable interface to this. In addition, many sites write custom tools for local needs to enforce local policies and provide levels of self service to users that aren't currently available with packaged tools."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:613(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:614(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:618(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:621(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:624(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:627(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:630(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:633(para) msgid "Username and email address are self-explanatory, though your site may have local conventions you should observe. Setting and changing passwords in the Identity Service requires administrative privileges. As of the Folsom release, users cannot change their own passwords. This is a large driver for creating local custom tools, and must be kept in mind when assigning and distributing passwords. The primary project is simply the first project the user is associated with and must exist prior to creating the user. Role is almost always going to be \"member\". Out of the box, OpenStack comes with two roles defined:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:646(para) msgid "\"member\": a typical user."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:649(para) msgid "\"admin\": an administrative super user which has full permissions across all projects and should be used with great care."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:654(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:656(para) msgid "Once you've gathered this information, creating the user in the Dashboard is just another web form similar to what we've seen before and can be found on the \"Users\" link in the \"Admin\" navigation bar and then clicking the \"Create User\" button at the top right."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:661(para) msgid "Modifying users is also done from this \"Users\" page. If you have a large number of users, this page can get quite crowded. The \"Filter\" search box at the top of the page can be used to limit the users listing. A form very similar to the user creation dialog can be pulled up by selecting \"Edit\" from the actions drop down menu at the end of the line for the user you are modifying."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:670(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:671(para) msgid "Many sites run with users being associated with only one project. This is a more conservative and simpler choice both for administration and for users. Administratively if a user reports a problem with an instance or quota it is obvious which project this relates to as well. Users needn't worry about what project they are acting in if they are only in one project. However, note that, by default, any user can affect the resources of any other user within their project. It is also possible to associate users with multiple projects if that makes sense for your organization."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:682(para) msgid "Associating existing users with an additional project or removing them from an older project is done from the \"Projects\" page of the Dashboard by selecting the \"Modify Users\" from the \"Actions\" column:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:692(para) msgid "Edit Project Members tab of the dashboard, from which you can perform actions on users."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:697(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:699(para) msgid "The first column of this form, titled \"All Users\", will include a list of all the users in your cloud who are not already associated with this project and the second all the users who are. These can be quite long, but can be limited by typing a substring of the user name you are looking for in the filter field at the top of the column."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:706(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:709(para) msgid "The dangerous possibility comes in the ability to change member roles. This is the drop down list after the user name in the Project Members list. In virtually all cases this value should be set to \"Member\". This example purposefully show and administrative user where this value is \"admin\"."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:714(para) msgid "The \"admin\" is global not per project so granting a user the admin role in any project gives the administrative rights across the whole cloud."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:717(para) msgid "Typical use is to only create administrative users in a single project, by convention the \"admin\" project which is created by default during cloud setup. If your administrative users also use the cloud to launch and manage instances it is strongly recommended that you use separate user accounts for administrative access and normal operations and that they be in distinct projects."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:726(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:727(para) msgid "The default authorization settings only allow administrative users to create resources on behalf of a different project. OpenStack handles two kind of authorization policies:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:733(para) msgid "Operation-based: policies specify access criteria for specific operations, possibly with fine-grained control over specific attributes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:741(para) msgid "Resource-based: whether access to a specific resource might be granted or not according to the permissions configured for the resource (currently available only for the network resource). The actual authorization policies enforced in an OpenStack service vary from deployment to deployment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:752(para) msgid "The policy engine reads entries from the policy.json file. The actual location of this file might vary from distribution to distribution, for nova it is typically in /etc/nova/policy.json. You can update entries while the system is running, and you do not have to restart services. Currently the only way to update such policies is to edit the policy file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:761(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:768(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:781(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:792(para) msgid "Role-based rules: evaluate successfully if the user submitting the request has the specified role. For instance \"role:admin\"is successful if the user submitting the request is an administrator."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:799(para) msgid "Field-based rules: evaluate successfully if a field of the resource specified in the current request matches a specific value. For instance \"field:networks:shared=True\" is successful if the attribute shared of the network resource is set to true."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:807(para) msgid "Generic rules: compare an attribute in the resource with an attribute extracted from the user's security credentials and evaluates successfully if the comparison is successful. For instance \"tenant_id:%(tenant_id)s\" is successful if the tenant identifier in the resource is equal to the tenant identifier of the user submitting the request."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:816(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:820(emphasis)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:821(emphasis)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:837(emphasis)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:840(para) msgid "[1] Shows a rule which evaluates successfully if the current user is an administrator or the owner of the resource specified in the request (tenant identifier is equal)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:843(para) msgid "[2] Shows the default policy which is always evaluated if an API operation does not match any of the policies in policy.json."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:846(para) msgid "[3] Shows a policy restricting the ability of manipulating flavors to administrators using the Admin API only."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:848(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:855(title) msgid "Users that Disrupt Other Users"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:856(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:860(para) msgid "For example: A group of users have instances that are utilizing a large amount of compute resources for very compute-intensive tasks. This is driving the load up on compute nodes and affecting other users. In this situation, review your user use cases. You may find that high compute scenarios are common and should then plan for proper segregation in your cloud such as host aggregation or regions."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:866(para) msgid "Another example is a user consuming a very large amount of bandwidth. Again, the key is to understand what the user is doing. If they naturally need a high amount of bandwidth, you might have to limit their transmission rate as to not affect other users or move them to an area with more bandwidth available. On the other hand, maybe the user's instance has been hacked and is part of a botnet launching DDOS attacks. Resolution to this issue is the same as if any other server on your network has been hacked. Contact the user and give them time to respond. If they don't respond, shut the instance down."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:875(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:884(para)

commit_message:
Added Backup/Restore validations

Added checks for backup-create API call to ensure
datastore supports backup strategy
Also for trove-create API call (when restoring from backup)
added checks to ensure that datastore version of backup
being restored matches with datastore version of
instance being created

Change-Id: I9f9cf76ce3d2533612515e6382a184e955e09a32
Closes-Bug: #1285876

subject: Uses explicit imports for _
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-27 13:53:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/48465e5e19a669c5fbe03446874b820440972fd9', 'message': 'Explicit `_` import

Due to deprecating unexplicit `_` import, explicit `_` become necessary.
But obvious it is done not everywhere. Sadly that tox does not reveal
the bug. To reproduce the bug please use nosetests.

commit_message:
Uses explicit imports for _

Previously `_` was monkeypatched in tests/core.py and bin/keystone-*.
This meant that if a developer was not running the tests exactly as
the documentation described they would not work. Even importing
certain modules in a interactive Python interpreter would fail unless
keystone.tests was imported first. Monkeypatching was removed and
explicit import for `_` was added.

Co-Authored-By: David Stanek <dstanek@dstanek.com>
Change-Id: I8b25b5b6d83fb873e25a8fab7686babf1d2261fa
Closes-Bug: #1255518
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/66/58766/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.openstack.common.gettextutils import _

subject: Skip test_authorization if we cannot create images
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-07 20:56:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/e73f3475f27ee2ff2640953e38e84f5cf9ff9ed8', 'message': 'Skip test_authorization if glance is not available

In keeping with the other tests which skip if dependent
services are not available, test_authorization should skip
if glance is not available. (tempest.api.compute.test_authorization)

commit_message:
Skip test_authorization if we cannot create images

The test_authorization test suite uses create_image without
checking if it is enabled or not, as is done in other
tests.

Change-Id: I882816054c68d72a4738717930275d3e6fa90f11
Closes-Bug: #1289583

added_lines: [array]$ExtraFeatures = @() $ExitCode = $parser.ExecuteBinary($SetupExe.FullName, @{"QS" = $null; "FEATURES" = @("SQLEngine", "Conn", "SSMS", "ADV_SSMS") + $ExtraFeatures}) Setup must be completed after booting rearmed machine by using Complete-SQLServerAfterSysPrep or Complete-SQLServerAfterSysPrepForAOAG cmdletfunction Complete-SQLServerAfterSysPrepForAOAG { <# .SYNOPSIS Completes previously prepared with "Install-SQLServerForSysPrep" MS SQL Server after the system was rearmed. Installs AlwaysOn availability features. .DESCRIPTION Completes previously prepared with "Install-SQLServerForSysPrep" MS SQL Server after the system was rearmed. Installs AlwaysOn availability features and any additional features specified. Returns $true if a reboot is required after the installation, $false if a reboot is not required and throws an exception in case if installation fails. .PARAMETER SetupRoot MS SQL Server installation files root directory. Normally it is just DVD drive name. .PARAMETER SQLSvcUsrDomain MS SQL Server user account domain name. .PARAMETER SQLSvcUsrName MS SQL Server user account name. .PARAMETER SQLSvcUsrPassword MS SQL Server user account password. .PARAMETER ExtraFeatures List of features to be installed besides "SQLEngine", "Conn", "SSMS", "ADV_SSMS", "DREPLAY_CTLR", "DREPLAY_CLT". #> param( [parameter(Mandatory = $true)] [string]$SetupRoot, [parameter(Mandatory = $true)] [string]$SQLSvcUsrDomain, [parameter(Mandatory = $true)] [string]$SQLSvcUsrName, [parameter(Mandatory = $true)] [string]$SQLSvcUsrPassword, [array]$ExtraFeatures = @() ) $SetupDir = Get-Item $SetupRoot $SetupExe = $SetupDir.GetFiles("setup.exe")[0] $SQLUser = "$SQLSvcUsrDomain\$SQLSvcUsrName" $domain = New-Object System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry("LDAP://$SQLSvcUsrDomain", $SQLSvcUsrName, $SQLSvcUsrPassword) if ($domain.name -eq $null) { throw "Credentials validation failed for user $SQLUser. Check domain, login name and password." } $parser = New-OptionParserCompleteImage $ExitCode = $parser.ExecuteBinary($SetupExe.FullName, @{"QS" = $null; "AGTSVCACCOUNT" = $SQLUser; "AGTSVCPASSWORD" = $SQLSvcUsrPassword; "SQLSVCACCOUNT" = $SQLUser; "SQLSVCPASSWORD" = $SQLSvcUsrPassword; "SQLSYSADMINACCOUNTS" = $SQLUser; "RSSVCACCOUNT" = $SQLUser; "RSSVCPASSWORD" = $SQLSvcUsrPassword}) $RebootRequired = $false if ($ExitCode -eq 3010) { RebootRequired = $true $ExitCode = 0 } if ($ExitCode -ne 0) { throw "Installation executable exited with code $("{0:X8}" -f $ExitCode) (Decimal: $ExitCode)" } $RebootRequired2 = New-SQLServerForAOAG -SetupRoot $SetupRoot -SQLSvcUsrDomain $SQLSvcUsrDomain -SQLSvcUsrName $SQLSvcUsrName -SQLSvcUsrPassword $SQLSvcUsrPassword -ExtraFeatures $ExtraFeatures return $RebootRequired -or $RebootRequired2 }
deleted_lines: [array]$ExtraFeatures = @(), [Hashtable]$ExtraOptions = @{} $ExitCode = $parser.ExecuteBinary($SetupExe.FullName, @{"Q" = $null; "FEATURES" = @("SQLEngine", "Conn", "SSMS", "ADV_SSMS") + $ExtraFeatures} + $ExtraOptions) Setup must be completed after booting rearmed machine by using Complete-SQLServer cmdlet

commit_message:
VMware: Clone snapshots to the Glance datastore

Glance contains a new backend store since Icehouse: the VMware store.
The Nova VMware driver should take advantage of it for snapshots:
instead of uploading the bits through the network, we move them
to the Glance datastore folder and register a new location for the
image. This makes the snapshot operation much faster.

This optimization is built on top of the image handler framework
using the push_image() api.

partially implements bp vmware-clone-image-handler

Change-Id: I7fdbed84749cfa9d9a440ba591a24bbac522d7ff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/93/79493/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _push_image(self, context, image_id, image_meta, path, purge_props=False, user_id=None, project_id=None, **kwargs): LOG.debug(_("Uploading image %s to the Glance image server") % image_id) host = kwargs.get('host') if host is None: LOG.error(_("Cannot push image %s with null host"), image_id) return False dc_path = kwargs.get('datacenter_path') if dc_path is None: LOG.error(_("Cannot push image %s with null datacenter path"), image_id) return False ds_name = kwargs.get('datastore_name') if ds_name is None: LOG.error(_("Cannot push image %s with null datastore name"), image_id) return False cookies = kwargs.get('cookies') if cookies is None: LOG.error(_("Cannot push image %s with null cookies"), image_id) return False read_file_handle = read_write_util.VMwareHTTPReadFile( host, dc_path, ds_name, cookies, path) file_size = read_file_handle.get_size() (image_service, image_id) = glance.get_remote_image_service( context, image_id) metadata = image_service.show(context, image_id) # The properties and other fields that we need to set for the image. image_metadata = {"disk_format": "vmdk", "is_public": "false", "name": metadata['name'], "status": "active", "container_format": "bare", "size": file_size, "properties": {"vmware_adaptertype": kwargs.get("adapter_type"), "vmware_disktype": kwargs.get("disk_type"), "vmware_ostype": kwargs.get("os_type"), "vmware_image_version": kwargs.get("image_version"), "owner_id": project_id}} vmware_images.start_transfer(context, read_file_handle, file_size, image_service=image_service, image_id=image_id, image_meta=image_metadata) LOG.debug(_("Uploaded image %s to the Glance image server") % image_id) return True, None, image_metadata

subject: Deploy VM to SDRS datastore cluster (Phase 1)
revisions:
[{'number': 13, 'created': '2014-01-24 07:09:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d530d8145a86eef1edbced9ab2f236b7d211cc0a', 'message': "Deploy VM to SDRS datastore cluster (Phase 1)

This code change intends to enable the capability of vmware driver
to deploy VM to SDRS enabled datastore cluster.

In order to implement that, two options need to be added to
nova.conf. The first option is 'datastore_cluster_name'. This option
allows the end user to specify the name of datastore cluster
(StoragePod object). The second option is 'use_SDRS'. This is a
boolean option. The end user can use it to specify whether or not to
utilize SDRS to select datastore. This option will have effect, only
if datastore_cluster_name is specified.

The VM image need to be a template in VCenter, so that SDRS will
automatically execute VM provisioning task.

If the image is a template in VCenter, and use_SDRS is false, vmware
driver need to select a datastore and call cloneVM_Task() to deploy
the VM. In this case, if datastore_cluster_name is speicified, it
will have effect to filter the datastores from user defined datastore
cluster.

If the image is a template in VCenter, and use_SDRS is true and
datastore_cluster_name is also speicified, vmware driver will call
RecommendDatastores() to deploy the VM. If SDRS is not fully automated,
ApplyStorageDrsRecommendation_Task() need to be called.

All these code changes will be proposed in two phases. In phase 1, only
selecting datastore from datastore cluster will be implemented. The code
to invoke RecommendDatastores() will be implemented in phase 2.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ic0cf74ea65ea90c15688d1ce0f874cf8b953e630
Partially implements: blueprint vmware-sdrs-datastore-cluster

commit_message:
Deploy VM to SDRS datastore cluster (Phase 1)

This code change intends to enable the capability of vmware driver
to deploy VM to SDRS enabled datastore cluster.

In order to implement that, two options need to be added to
nova.conf. The first option is 'datastore_cluster_name'. This option
allows the end user to specify the name of datastore cluster
(StoragePod object). The second option is 'use_SDRS'. This is a
boolean option. The end user can use it to specify whether or not to
utilize SDRS to select datastore. This option will have effect, only
if datastore_cluster_name is specified.

The VM image need to be a template in VCenter, so that SDRS will
automatically execute VM provisioning task.

If the image is a template in VCenter, and use_SDRS is false, vmware
driver need to select a datastore and call cloneVM_Task() to deploy
the VM. In this case, if datastore_cluster_name is speicified, it
will have effect to filter the datastores from user defined datastore
cluster.

If the image is a template in VCenter, and use_SDRS is true and
datastore_cluster_name is also speicified, vmware driver will call
RecommendDatastores() to deploy the VM. If SDRS is not fully automated,
ApplyStorageDrsRecommendation_Task() need to be called.

All these code changes will be proposed in two phases. In phase 1, only
selecting datastore from datastore cluster will be implemented. The code
to invoke RecommendDatastores() will be implemented in phase 2.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ic0cf74ea65ea90c15688d1ce0f874cf8b953e630
Partially implements: blueprint vmware-sdrs-datastore-cluster
